scenes.location: FLETCHER/MARINA APT. LIVING ROOM, BROOKLYN. DAY 1
characters: D73 INT/EXT. JEFFERSON AVENUE SUBWAY STATION STEPS D73
INT. AFTER HOURS GAY CLUB. LATE NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on Cornelia Srebnick, 41. She’s humming softly. We MOVE out slowly to see she’s rocking the infant on a big comfortable couch fionlled with baby blankets, stuffed animals and children’s books. We MOVE over to see Josh Srebnick, 44, on the floor watch her -- his expression a kind of awe. She looks at him, hesitating, taken by the intensity of his look. A moment connection and warmth passes through her. He smiles softly back.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: (to the baby) There were three little pigs and they made a house out of twigs and the wolf came and... (to Josh) Do you remember how it goes?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: He blows it down? The baby starts to fuss.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: Yeah. But, what happens in the middle?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (thinks ) I keep wanting to do this little piggie went to market but that’s with the toes. The baby starts to cry.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: The wolf keeps blowing the house in. The pigs keep making different houses. (rocks the baby) Oh...shh, shh, shh. The baby is wailing. Cornelia rocks her faster. She looks panicked.  Pink (09/30/2013) 2.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: What the fuck do we do? Josh doesn't know. Bang, a door opens and a woman comes i with a boppy strapped around her waist. This is Marina, 30's.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: Okay, who’s ready to eat?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH MARINA
dialogues.text: Are we taking in or -- Who’s ready to eat? She sits down on the couch next to Cornelia, lifts the sobbing infant from out of Cornelia’s arms and places it the boppy. The baby’s onesie has an image from The Clash’ first album across the chest. Marina opens her bra and gi the baby her breast. The baby nurses, stretches and stops crying.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: Ha! I love how she stretches...it’s just like we do... It’s so funny. It never occurred to me that stretching is innate. She stretches, imitating the baby. Cornelia smiles polite A curly haired man with glasses, early 40's, enters. Flet

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: You want to see it?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Yeah. Fletcher sits near Josh.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: It got infected with staph but it’s not the bad staph. He pushes up his sleeve to reveal a square black and whit tattoo on his bicep.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: Guess. (to Josh) You can come closer it’s not the bad staph.  He shoves Pink (09/30/2013)

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: I still don’t want the baby touching it. his shoulder in Josh’s face.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I can’t...tell.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: It’s Willow’s sonogram.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Oh...okay.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: I did it for Marina. I was so fucking proud of her.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: Why it’s for me, I still don’t understand.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Where do you even go for a tattoo?

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: I asked a guy at work and he told me where his kids went. Place in Williamsburg. Where else? (pause) You know, she didn’t get the epidurol.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: It’s a mother fucker -- it’s a ring of fucking fire -- but it was the most beautiful experience of my life.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: And I fell in love immediately. A love I’ve never felt. I mean, don’t take that the wrong way, Marina --

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: No, I know exactly what you mean. It’s pure.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: (how sweet) Aww...

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: (can’t help herself) Oh, you guys should do it!

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: Yeah!

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: You’d make such good parents. (catching herself) I’m sorry, I’m sorry!

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: No, it’s fine. You know, we -- She looks at Josh.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH MARINA
dialogues.text: We... It’s just such a game changer! We STAY on Josh and Cornelia’s faces.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: When I saw her, I thought: “I know you.”

dialogues.speaker: MARINA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It’s true, I recognized her immediately.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: And because I'd been reading to her in the womb, she knew my voice immediately.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It’s like in one moment, I read her Stephen King’s The + everything is different. Tommyknockers.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It’s like all the stuff before, fine, you know, we’re figuring it out, but now: Okay, real life. You know? Josh and Cornelia nod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cornelia and Josh walk home.  Pink (09/30/2013) 4a. INT. JOSH AND CORNELIA’S APARTMENT. DAY 2 They enter. An open floor-through of a brownstone. The room, separated by large wooden pocket doors, looks half- finished, framed pictures lean against the wall, projects undertaken and abandoned. Some nice stuff, a couple of antique chairs or a table. A water stain untended to on t ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can’t remember Goldilocks either anymore. The porridge part, but not what happens.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: She gets eaten, right?

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: Does she?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: There’s like an oven that’s too hot. Josh shrugs. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: You don’t want kids, right? (Josh hesitates) Because I don’t. (they both hesitate) I’m sorry, I feel so guilty for saying that. I mean, I did. If we'd had the magic sexy version and one day suddenly had a baby... But all those drugs and shots and miscarriages -- I don’t want to do it again and it not to work.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I know. (beat) And I like our life as it is.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: (relieved) Me too.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I don’t want things to be different than they are right now.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: I know. I mean, if we wanted to take off for Paris tomorrow, we could.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Yeah, I mean I think it would be hard to find an affordable fare on such short notice, but yeah...

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: No, I know and I couldn’t leave work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we were going to do it we should plan it at least a month in advance.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: A month is still in the realm of spontaneity.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: No, I know. I mean, the time we spent in Rome, what was that --

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (can’t believe it) It wasn’t 2006.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: Yeah because I was working with my dad on his dance film.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Rome was eight years ago already? Shit.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: Yeah, I looked at the pictures recently and we’re two younger people standing at the Treve Fountain.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: We look similar.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: We look younger. (pause) I tried to get you to go to Mexico last summer --

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I needed to finish my documentary.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: But you didn’t finish it! They both take a deep breath. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Well, maybe the point is we have the freedom. What we do with it isn’t that important.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: Marina said they haven't had sex in nearly a year. Fletcher was too weirded out by the pregnancy.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They eat Thai take-out at a table set for two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They do dishes. INT. JOSH/CORNELIA APT. - BEDROOM, COBBLE HILL, BROOKLYN.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: Josh, in his boxers, takes off his watch and puts it on t night table. Cornelia undresses. They move about in silence, finishing their nighttime routines. Only the sounds of footsteps, water running, clothes coming off and going on, bed squeaks. Josh lies on his back and shuts his eyes. Cornelia gets in bed and clicks on her bedside lamp which lights up nearly everything. Josh places his arm over his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: What is that, a seventy-five watt? She looks under the shade.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: I can’t see, it’s too bright.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: It’s too high a wattage.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: I‘1l change it tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josh paces back and forth in his home-office. His editor, Tim, early 30’s, sits at a desk-top attached to a series drives. A tousled scholar, Ira Mandelstam, 50’s, talks gravely on a TV screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was a poll conducted in 1987 in which people were given a series of phrases and asked which ones could be found in the US Constitution --

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Let me see the continuity...

dialogues.speaker: SCHOLAR, (ON SCREEN)
dialogues.text: One of the phrases that got the highest percentage of votes was: “From each according to his ability, to each according to his need.” This, of course, is not to be found in the Constitution, but is the famous Communist credo popularized by Karl Marx. Josh takes the sheet and holds it about two feet from his face. He squints.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Why do they type this stuff so small?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: I think that’s 12 point. That’s normal.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOLAR, (ON SCREEN)
dialogues.text: However, when this phrase was That is not 12, that’s at presented to people as a most eight. Look at it, it’s tenet of Communism, they, of tiny. course, overwhelmingly rejected it.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: We need to cut away from Ira here because... We hear a ringing. On the SCREEN: the scholar goes into h pants pocket and retrieves a cell phone from a few years

dialogues.speaker: SCHOLAR, (ON SCREEN)
dialogues.text: Hold on... He looks at it like he’s never seen anything like it befo He puts on reading glasses and very deliberately presses Talk.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOLAR, (ON SCREEN)
dialogues.text: Hello?...Evelyn, I’m doing an interview...Did you look in the car? This is every fucking day, sweety! (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I keep telling you: put them on a fucking chain around your neck! (mouths to the camera) Sorry. (back to the phone) Sweety, if you don’t stop this, I’m going to fucking screa -- Tim freezes the image on the screen.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: We could cut to me asking the question about hermeneutics?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: We could, but you look like this in that footage -- He shows an image of a younger Josh in a goatee and Jew-f

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: It’s from eight years ago. And the previous shot of you asking any relevant questions is this -- He pulls up an image of Josh with short hair and his arm sling.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: That’s from when I fell down the subway stairs at Grand Army Plaza. The blizzard of 06? You remember how icy that was? We CUT between a series of Joshes from over the years. Different hair lengths, a beard, a brief moustache, a bla eye.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: You remember, I was trying my part on the other side. Tim doesn't.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: God, eight years ago. Has it been that long?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: It’s been ten.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (counting in his head, rationalizing) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: JOSH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ten this fall. Nine and a half. Look at my jaw -- I had more baby fat. (looks at his reflection in the computer screen) Are my eyes getting hollows?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (trying to be positive) Well...we’re getting there. Tim looks at him, totally skeptical.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: When the rest of the grant money comes in, we'll reshoot me asking the questions along with the trip to Istanbul.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Hey, Josh, I hate to bring this up, but I’m gonna need a little money soon.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: No, I know, you've been patient. I’m just waiting for the rest of this last grant money.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: But soon?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Yeah, I’1l get you. Goes into his wallet.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: You need anything now? He hands Tim a couple of twenties.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: You know, get Maggie some flowers or...

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: I’m going to use it to buy food.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah, yeah...good idea.  Blue (09/16/2013) 11.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A room with about fifty chairs, about seven of them occup by people over 50. Josh stands at a lectern with a lap to A blank TV screen behind him.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: “Le documentaire, c'est ce qui arrive aux autres, la fiction, c'est ce qui m'arrive a moi.” “Documentary is about someone else. Fiction is about me.” (glances out at the small crowd, having made it through the French part) This is a quote from Jean-Luc Godard. Now, what do we think about this? Can a documentary be personal? Documentaries, I want to say to you today, can and should be about me. Josh hesitates. A guy in the audience wearing a porkpie h is filming him with a portable camera. Josh is momentaril distracted.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Me meaning all of us. (to the room) Lights. (pause) Frank, can you just hit that switch? An elderly gentleman obliges. Josh hits a button on his l top.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: This is an image from -- Nothing happens on the screen behind him. Josh presses th button again. Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Well...shit...this should be an image of seal hunting from “Nanook of The North.” CUT TO: Josh collects his things from a chair at the foot the stage. A squat woman, 50’s, who runs the lecture seri shrugs and smiles tightly at him.

dialogues.speaker: SQUAT WOMAN
dialogues.text: Sorry.  Blue (09/16/2013) lia.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (suddenly paranoid) About what?  Blue (09/16/2013) 12. The guy, 25, who was shooting Josh, comes forward. He wea his mussed hair under his porkpie hat, an old plaid shirt hanging out over slacks, and beat up boots. This is Jamie

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Hey. Beautiful class.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Oh...thanks. I don’t know why the power point didn’t work, but...

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: I loved what you said about “hyper- reality.” I’m Jamie.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH JAMIE
dialogues.text: Josh Srebnick. This is my wife, Darby. A girl, 23, in a high waisted dress and lace up boots com forward.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: Hi. Nice to meet you. It was interesting.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Thanks. I’m not sure why the power point didn’t work... How did you get in here?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: We're auditing your class.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: It’s a continuing education class, you can’t audit a continuing education class.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: (shrugs) I’m a fan. And hey, I really loved your film, Power Elite.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (taken aback, can’t hide his pleasure) You've seen it? Hey...thanks.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: It’s everything I aspire to and you make it look so easy.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Do you make documentaries?  Blue (09/16/2013) 13.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: I shoot stuff, you know, with friends, yeah. Nothing like you’re doing.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: He’s always shooting.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Um, don’t take this the wrong way, but how did you see Power Elite?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: I found a VHS on Ebay. I paid like sixty dollars for it. You know what was great, was that scene with the dogs around the garbage? How did you stage that?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Oh...those dogs were just there and I said, “Hey shoot those dogs.” (not a great story) And...we did.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: (claps his hands together) Beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I’ve been working on this other one for...about eight years now but I think I’m zeroing in on it.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: I'd love to see it.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: When I was a child my dog was killed in front of me by two rottweilers. (she starts to laugh) I don’t know why I’m laughing. It’s not funny. I was five. My dad and I were walking our poodle which I had named Toto and these two rottweilers came bounding out of an open gate and just attacked. My dad flagged down a passing car and we climbed in the back and he covered my eyes so I couldn’t see Toto get mauled. She covers her face, she’s still laughing.  14.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (hesitates) I’m sorry to hear that.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: You want to come get a bite with us?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Oh...I’m meeting my...wife around the corner at this Chinese place.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Hey, my wife and I are going to the same goddamn place!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josh and Cornelia sit next to each other. Josh is in the middle of talking to Jamie and Darby who face them across table.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: ...I’ve learned along the way that you can discover more by not knowing the answers, by allowing yourself to be surprised by what you encounter. Jamie nods with great interest.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Sometimes that means waiting years for something to happen. I don’t know. I could go on about this stuff for days.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: How did you start out, like who influenced you?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Oh, I steal from everyone, you know, Maysles, Wiseman, Pennebaker... My first job out of graduate school was working for Leslie Breitbart.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: (impressed) Jeez Louise.  15.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: That’s also incidentally how I met Cornelia. He’s her dad.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: What?!

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: This is before they hated each other.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: We don’t hate each other. Cornelia produces her dad’s films.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: He’s amazing.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: Yeah, he’s kind of annoying me right now, but...yeah.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: He’s a giant. He’s a guy I’d love to meet. Do you also produce Josh's films?

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: No, Josh likes to work alone.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: (again with real interest, to Josh) Josh, what's your new film about?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Well, I’m trying to solve the problem that Eisenstein never solved -- that is how to make a film that is both materialist and intellectual at the same time -- Darby gets a text and starts to reply. Jamie yawns openly Josh feels he’s losing his audience but keeps going.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: It’s about the distinctly American relationship between biography and history, theory and method and how that relates to power and class in our country, particularly the political, military and economic elite. (sensing he’s lost them) It’s really about America.  Blue (09/16/2013) 16. Jamie takes out a pad and pen and scribbles something dow

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Eisenstein is astonishing. I just saw Strike! I’m obsessed with Europe in the 20’s, see. The interwar period, ex-patriots, that sort of thing.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: I keep trying to get Jamie to do something with before and afters. All humans love before and afters. Any TV show with before and afters will succeed.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: (smiles broadly) Before you said that. (Jamie frowns) After you said that.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: (shakes her head) Fuck you. He grabs her breast she smacks his hand playfully and ret to her phone and answers a text. Cornelia tries an accommodating smile.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: What do you do, Darby?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Darby makes ice cream.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah?

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: (shrugs, texting) Yeah, I make ice cream.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: I brought it over to the Whole Foods near us and they’re pumped.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: It’s Jamie’s idea to sell it, I just do it because I like it.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: And you guys are married?  Blue (09/16/2013) 16A. They both nod in unison.  17.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: That’s so nice and old fashioned.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. We said our vows in an empty water tower in Harlem.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: There was a mariachi band and a slip and slide.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Wow.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY JAMIE
dialogues.text: Jamie wanted a big wedding. It was amazing. Some rituals exist for a reason, you know.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: (glances at Josh) Yeah. We did it at city hall.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: (looking up from a text) Isaac and Benny are walking the tracks.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Have you guys done this? We walked through the subway tunnels on the D line last week.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (as if it’s commonplace) No, no, we haven’t.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: They’re at a Bar on Essex. You want to come?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (to Cornelia) Oh, do we -- ?

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: It’s already past our bedtime.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (sheepishly) Yeah, we’re usually in bed by eleven.  Blue (09/16/2013) 18. The check is placed on the table. Anticipating some resistance, Josh puts his hand on the check.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Let me get it.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: (eagerly) Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: Yeah, thanks. Josh's hand remains on the check in preparation for it to taken from him. Nothing happens.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: No, yeah, I'll get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamie and Darby unlock their bikes which are chained to a street-sign with old-school bike chains. Jamie attaches t chain to his pants like an accessory.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: If you’ve got any time -- and I know you’re super busy -- I’d love to show you what I’m working on.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: Come by our place this weekend. (to Cornelia) I have my fall flavors. Jamie gives Josh an old Polaroid of himself and writes hi number on it with a sharpie. His handwriting is in all ca very precise.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: They don’t make this film anymore. I bought four hundred packs before they discontinued it. Jamie, without a helmet, hops on his bike which has a crocheted seat. Darby is still tying her helmet.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Let’s go, worm! (to Josh and Cornelia) Peace.  Pink (09/30/2013) 19.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: (to Josh and Cornelia) Jamie is always moving. I can’t leap as fast as that kid. I don’t move as quickly. They both pedal into the center of the street. The streetlight giving them a kind of glow. We MOVE in on Jos and Cornelia. They don’t know what hit them.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I like how engaged they are in everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cornelia is reading on her Kindle. Josh stands in the bathroom doorway.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: Mm.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: They're all making things and they’re so excited for each other. It’s selfless. They were so respectful of us. I mean, compared to when we go out with Fletcher and Marina I feel like we're all just talking about ourselves... They asked questions.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: They didn’t ask me any questions.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: When I was their age I would never have come up to me like that and invited me out. I would have been too scared... They’re really not nervous.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: I wish you hadn’t told him I work with my dad.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: I don’t know, he seems ambitious.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: No! I don’t think he thinks that way. It’s about process.  He climbs Blue (09/16/2013) 20.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: How has he even seen anything of yours?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (like it should be obvious) Ebay. (scanning the room) I love his shoes. I have some wing tips here somewhere. into bed.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: It was almost like he was studying you.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Can we go to their place this weekend?

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: We never see our real friends, why are we suddenly going to hang out with a couple of twenty-five year olds.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: We were just twenty-five. I mean, we weren’t, but you know. It’1l be fun. CUT TO: CLOSE on a woman, 25, scrolling through the addre on her phone.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Um, let’s see, it would probably be...Richard Dreyfuss. He’s an old friend of my parents.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Um, this girl who was a writer on that show, Medium. YELLOW BLOCK TEXT on the screen: Who’s the most famous pe in your cell phone?

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Doug Liman. Guy #2 Bill Clinton. But I think it’s probably his office.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Patrick Ewing’s brother. Carl.  21. Guy #2 (now on his phone) Ringing. (pause) Yeah, it’s his office.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Robert Downey. Senior.

dialogues.speaker: INT. JAMIE/DARBY APT, BUSHWICK. DAY
dialogues.text: Jamie watches Josh and Cornelia watch the short on his computer. They’re both smiling. Darby hovers in the background, holding a white kitten, she’s seen it.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: That’s really funny.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: Yeah. I like Robert Downey. Senior.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: That’s the latest anyway. I’m also doing people describing scenes from movies that they like but haven't seen in a while. Darby’s going to do Rosemary's Baby, see. Josh and Cornelia look back at Darby. She obliges:

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: What have you done to its eyes!?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (playing along) He has his father’s eyes. Cornelia pets the kitten in Darby’s arms.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: I want a kitten!

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: That’s Bad Cop. Where’s Good Cop? A black kitten comes out from under the couch. Darby hand the white one to Cornelia and gathers the other one.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: I love these kittens, but I hope they don’t grow up to be assholes because that can happen.  22.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: This is a great space. You know I think I’ve only been to Williamsburg once before.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: This isn’t even Williamsburg, it’s Bushwick. We were in Williamsburg, before then Park Slope, now we're here. (shrugs) We live where we’re supposed to live. She indicates a series of old typewriters.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: Jamie’s a collector. My decorating sensibilities veer towards 4th grade teacher. I like bulletin boards. We see the place now. It’s old, open, and has the feel of being haphazardly curated: from the mouse trap stuck to t molding to the flea market furniture to the VHS tapes of random movies stacked against the wall. A framed NY Times front page of the moon landing. A framed Polish poster of the Bob Dylan doc “Don’t Look Back.” A photo of Darby goi down a slip and slide in her wedding dress. Josh looks at a stack of records. Velvet Underground, Kin John Coltrane, Suicide, Serge Gainsbourg, Thin Lizzy...

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: This looks like my record collection. Except mine are CD’s. It took me years to discover this stuff. Jamie smiles and puts a record on the turntable. A Notori B.I.G/Miley Cyrus mash-up. Josh admires a long wooden des with a computer and editing equipment.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I need to buy a new desk.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: You should come with me to the lumber yard. We’ll make one.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: A whole desk?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: It’s so much cheaper than buying one, see. And more fun. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Joshy, don’t overpay at some douche farm like a chump. A dark haired girl, 26, appears, in underwear and a T-shi with the drawing of a gun as if it’s tucked into her pant

dialogues.speaker: TIPPER
dialogues.text: Darby, can I borrow your bike, I’m going to the deli for Goldfish.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: Okay -- Tipper lifts her long bare leg and scratches the bottom o her foot.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Tipper, did you feed Nico?

dialogues.speaker: TIPPER
dialogues.text: (disappearing into the other room) I forgot. Off Cornelia’s perplexed look:

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: (with a hint of disdain) That’s our roommate, Tipper. Jamie grabs a bag of bird seed from a counter, he opens a small door that leads to an outdoor landing. A chicken pa in a cage. Cornelia hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: Nico’s a chicken. CUT TO: They sit around a small table. Darby prepares something in the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I have to say I really admire how you guys are so in the moment and just enjoying doing and making things. It’s inspiring.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Thanks, Joshy.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: The people our age are so success and results oriented, they've forgotten about process.  24.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Josh, are you success oriented?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH CORNELIA
dialogues.text: No. Totally. Josh looks at Cornelia, surprised. A crash from the kitch Darby reenters, shaking her head.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: I feel like there are people who don’t drop things as much as I do. (to Cornelia) I don’t keep things yar.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: She’s a mess. And an ugly eater. I say that with love.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: (playful) Fuck you. Darby places down a home-made container with a hipster co it and four spoons. She and Jamie eat straight from the container. Josh and Cornelia follow.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: It’s an avocado and almond milk sorbet. Benny designed the container.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: It tastes like that candy that they sometimes make into pigs or little fruits.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Yeah, it’s... Shit. I know that.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: I keep wanting to say baklava, but that’s a Greek dessert.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Right... “The almond tasting pigs and fruits are made of...” Josh pulls out his phone.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (realizes, excited) I‘1l look it up.  Al0

dialogues.speaker: B10
dialogues.text: clo

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: No, that’s too easy.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: Let’s try to remember it. They all sit in silence, racking their brains.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: How long until we decide we don’t know?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (re: his phone) Can I...now?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: No, let’s just not know what it is. CUT TO: Technology MONTAGE: INT. JOSH/CORNELIA APT. DAY Al0 Cornelia reads her Kindle. Josh watches a Daily Show vide on his phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamie removes a VHS tape of The Howling from a beat up bo and slides it into the VCR. INT. JOSH/CORNELIA APT. DAY c10 Josh streams a movie on Apple TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darby puts a worn Kris Kristofferson record on a turntabl She secures old-fashioned headphones to her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cornelia selects a NPR podcast from her iPod mini and put her sleek noise-reduction Bose headphones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamie types a letter on an old IBM Selectric typewriter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josh plays a video game on his iPad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 110 10 Pink (09/30/2013) 26. The chicken sleeps in his cage. END MONTAGE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO: CLOSE on a text being typed: Joshy, street beach in effect! get your goddamn self to t wick for bourbon and ice creeeeem. CUT TO: CLOSE on a hand receiving the same text.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We have news!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josh sneaks a look at his text, smiles. Fletcher and Mari Josh and Cornelia sit at a table at the window. Throughou the conversation, everyone is dealing with his/her phone.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: I decided, with Marina going back to work, I’m taking a leave of absence from the firm and am going to take care of Willow.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Oh...cool. How long?

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: Indefinite.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: It’s such a load off and I’m making enough --

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: Yeah, it’s really just my ego at stake.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH FLETCHER
dialogues.text: Time to rewatch Mr. Mom. Already Netflixed it. I got some laughs.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: We're the boring couple with the baby. What have you guys been doing? Tell us something fun!

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Well, we met this interesting couple. Jamie and Darby. He’s a young documentarian and she makes ice cream.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: I don’t know what to make of them honestly. I like her.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: They make everything. It’s infectious. For about twelve hours I thought I could build my own desk.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: There is something about being around them that...that energizes you. You know?

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: How old are they?

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA JOSH
dialogues.text: (looks to Josh) 26 or 27. I think around 26.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: They’re children!

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: Nine years ago, they couldn’t vote.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: But they’re married.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: Why? Josh squints at his menu. He picks up a candle and holds close to the menu in order to read.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: You should see this guy’s record collection. It’s Jay-Z, it’s Thin Lizzy, it’s Mozart. Their taste is democratic. It’s The Goonies and Citizen Kane. They don’t distinguish between high and low, it’s wonderful.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: When did The Goonies become a good movie?

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: It’s like their apartment is full of everything we once threw out but it looks so good the way they have it.  Pink (09/30/2013) 28. Silence. Josh feels his phone vibrate. He starts texting. Everyone else takes this opportunity to text as well. Fletcher looks up.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: (re: texting) Why is it once one person goes on their phone everyone else has to.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA MARINA
dialogues.text: (distracted, on her (distracted, on her phone) phone) I just have a quick thing-- I’m not on my phone. I’m just... The baby.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: Each of us is so certain that we’ve got the most important thing to do right now...

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: (texting) I know, it’s rude.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: (texting) It’s not anymore. It used to be but now it’s accepted. It’s like showing your ankles in the 1800's. Josh gets a text. He lights up.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: The almond tasting pigs and fruits are made of... CLOSE: Marzipan! He and Cornelia both exclaim, laughing:

dialogues.speaker: JOSH/CORNELIA
dialogues.text: Marzipan!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s still light out. They emerge from the restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (to Fletcher and Marina) You guys want to hit this street beach with us?  Pink (09/30/2013) 28a.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: I don’t know what you’re saying.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Something Jamie and Darby are doing.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: Since when do you guys do two things in an evening? You never go anywhere.  Pink (09/30/2013) 29,

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (defensive) We go anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: We have to get back for the sitter...Scratch that, we want to get back.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: I hate being away from her!

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: The sitter?

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: Yeah! (beat) No, Willow.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA FLETCHER
dialogues.text: You should see how much he It’s true. cries when he has to leave her.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: Oh, we’ve lost you to the baby!

dialogues.speaker: MARINA FLETCHER
dialogues.text: You guys have to come see her We're always home so just again! She’s already a stop by! different person. They kiss and hug goodbye. They part ways.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: (now to Josh) We have lost them to the baby.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: We go anywhere. Right?

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: We never go anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: TIPPER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: High kick contest!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on an open fire hydrant hemorrhaging water.  30. Tipper, in a a home-made, totally unofficial t-shirt that says I’ve Been To A Lot of Hard Rock Cafes, kicks her leg high in the air. Guys in vintage plaid shorts and porkpie hats and beards and bare feet try to kick higher. Most everyone is filming everyone. Young women in swim suits t a beach ball. Jamie, with an apron that says Kiss the Chef, finishes kicking and sees Josh and Cornelia approaching. He bright and waves.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: What’s the rumpus, Srebnicks? Darby hands Cornelia a pinkish drink in a clear plastic c

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: Have you tried this? Someone at college figured out that if you put Jolly Ranchers in vodka for twenty- four hours -- it’s awesome. (nods to herself) Some kind of date rape genius. Cornelia drinks, she nods.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: I’d rape me.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: You want to take a dance class with me?

dialogues.speaker: BENNY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Ow fuck! Benny, a bearded white kid in an afro, sits at the curb, wincing and pulling a piece of glass out of his foot. Jam and Josh wade through the bathers to a hibachi grill.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Can I run an idea by you?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Sure, what?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: It’s a project I want to shoot.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Okay.  31.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: I’ve never done Facebook, it’s not my thing, see --

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Oh, really? I was against it at first...but it’s actually quite a useful tool. It makes me feel like I’m really connected. And there’s pictures-- A beach-ball hits Josh in the head.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: What the shit? Watch it! He realizes very quickly that he over-reacted, tries to b good sport and tosses the ball back with a forced laugh.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Ha! Back atcha!

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: It’s lame, yeah. That’s why I’m doing this new thing with it: I’m going to start a profile and wait for people to contact me.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Well, that part’s normal, that’s Facebook. Josh is doused with water from some splashing partiers. H tries to continue unfettered. He wrings out his shirt sle

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: And whoever the first person is from my childhood -- someone I’m no longer in touch with -- who contacts me...instead of responding on Facebook, see. I’m going to go find them in person. With my camera.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Like make Facebook real. It’s like you want to talk to me, let’s talk.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Kind of just like real life?  13 32.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Exactly.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Well, real was there before Facebook.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Right!

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: It sounds interesting. I’m not sure it’s enough --

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Well, think about what you want to say. I mean, what are you hoping to find?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: I’1l1 know when I get there. You said, we should be open to surprises, right?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: It’s a nice beginning. But it might not be a full enough meal yet, you know? Keep digging. Jamie nods, trying to mask his disappointment.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOLAR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: When I criticize quantitative analysis, it’s not because statistics don’t tell us anything. INT. IRA’S LIVING ROOM. DAY 13 Books and papers and yapping dogs. Tim holds a boom. Josh looks through the eye piece of a digital camera on a trip Ira, the scholar, older than we saw him on the Avid, now sports a mostly gray goatee. He has stained khakis, cheap running sneakers and a band-aid on his forehead.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOLAR
dialogues.text: On the contrary, I’d say that they are often very revealing. Indeed, they are often most revealing when -- (pause) I have to go to the gents.  14 33.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Okay. The scholar gets up --

dialogues.speaker: JOSH/TIM
dialogues.text: Wait, wait/Wait! The scholar is yanked back by the lavaliere mike pinned t his lapel. Josh and Tim both rush to his aid, unhooking h He shuffles to the bathroom and pees with the door open.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I guess he’s just doing that.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Yeah. Hey, Josh, how’s that grant money doing? Josh immediately goes into his wallet.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I’m expecting an email any day now which should confirm -- Josh offers him a few twenties.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: No, thanks, but the rest of the grant money is coming, yes?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Ye-s. Assuming they’re funded again for the next calendar year

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I don’t know, one of the donors left his wife and...I don’t know -- they’re confirming the funding.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Why'd he leave his wife?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cornelia carries a grocery bag, she listens to her iPod, singing aloud. She sees someone off-camera and smiles broadly.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: Hey Fox!  Pink (09/30/2013) 34. A few feet ahead coming her way: Marina carries Willow in Baby Bjorn next to two other younger mothers, early 30's, holding young children.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: Hey Foxy Fox!

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: I was just going to call you to see if you wanted to get lunch.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: Oh, how sweet. This is Pepper and Elise. This is Cornelia.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA PEPPER/ELISE
dialogues.text: Hey. Hi./Nice to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: We're going to a music class.

dialogues.speaker: ELISE
dialogues.text: It’s really just for the mothers, they don’t do anything yet.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: Do you want to come?

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: Oh...maybe...

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: Come on, then! Cornelia starts walking with the mothers.

dialogues.speaker: ELISE
dialogues.text: How old are your kids?

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: Mine? I don’t have any.

dialogues.speaker: ELISE
dialogues.text: Oh...I didn’t...you were just coming to hang out. Cool.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: It’s adorable. If you didn’t know better you think they’re having seizures!  15 16 17 Pink (09/30/2013) 35.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brightly lit with solid primary colors. A guy, 20’s anda girl, 20's sing a song about trains as mothers and nannie bounce their babies and sing along. Cornelia, her lap emp sits next to Marina, less enthusiastically singing along. She looks embarrassed and miserable. Cornelia whispers something in Marina’s ear. Marina protests, but Cornelia is insistent. Cornelia gets up and winds her way through singing mommies and babies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cornelia comes out of the building, her breathing raspy a shallow. She leans against the brick and composes herself

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: Holy shit... She takes out her phone and dials a number --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darby and Cornelia walk together.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: I mean, I love her, she’s a great mom, but I always felt like if I had a baby, the baby would just fold into to my life. I mean, if you spend all your time at baby classes, you become a baby. It’s like the mothers are infantilized. You know?

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: (talking generally) I know, just like: have a baby. You’re cool, you know cool people who have a house and, I don’t know, just have a baby. You’re going to Mexican food and there’s a baby on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: I know. That’s how I grew up.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: I want a baby. Maybe I’1l just have a baby right now.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: You should. You can.  18 Blue (09/16/2013) 36.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: I like kids who don’t speak English. (pause) When are you going to have babies?

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: (hesitates) A couple of times I got pregnant but it didn’t happen.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: The longest only went four weeks. After thirty-five it’s a shit-show.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. You don’t have to tell me.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: No, it’s okay. It’s what happened. I like telling you. (smiles, shrugs) I like our life as it is. I think. Even if we did have a kid, neither of us can cook. You can’t get baby take- out. Darby opens a door to a building and they start up a narr staircase.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: I like how you give Josh a hard time.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: I don’t think I give him a hard time. They enter a dance room filled almost entirely with black Filipino and Latina women.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: It reminds me of my mom.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: How she was with your dad?

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: No, with my brother. Cornelia frowns.  19 20 21 22 23 37.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: Yeah, she'd yell at him but iron all his weird racing T-shirts. I mother Jamie. Darby smells her underarms and makes a face.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: Sorry, I stink. She changes into a tank-top and baggy track pants. Cornel puts on a leotard.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: What kind of class is this again? They enter a crowded dance studio.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: Hip hop. Tupac’s “Hit Em Up” blasts on and the women start doing 9 music video dance moves. Cornelia tries to keep up, but looks less like a fly girl than a farmer doing a hoe-down Tupac continues over:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josh and Jamie admire the hats in the window. Josh points an Irish cap. Jamie shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamie, Darby, Cornelia and Josh (in his new porkpie hat w he’1l wear from now on) walk along the outdoor tracks. A train rushes by on another track. Darby squeals with delight. Jamie whoops. Cornelia and Josh look terrified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamie is the only white guy in a pick-up game on an aspha court.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josh runs on a treadmill. INT. JOSH AND CORNELIA’S APARTMENT. NIGHT 23 Josh tosses his hat onto a chair. He pulls Cornelia’s shi over her head. She unbuttons his pants. Their open mouths crash into one another. They make love on the floor.  24 25 26 Blue (09/16/2013) 38.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamie and Josh browse different bikes. Josh checks out an elaborate ten speed. Jamie shakes his head and points to single speed vintage, shitty-looking Raleigh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josh, a helmet strapped to his head, and Jamie, helmetles ride their bikes. Jamie lifts up his arms, soaking it all in. Josh tries to do the same. Josh looks suddenly disconcerted and grabs his side. He slows to a stop as we CONTINUE with Jamie soaring onward. INT. DOCTOR’S OFFICE. DAY 26 Josh sits on an examining table. A bald doctor is inspect his legs.

dialogues.speaker: DR. NAGATO
dialogues.text: Well, it’s a just strained muscle. But the more concerning thing here is your arthritis.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Arthritis?

dialogues.speaker: DR. NAGATO
dialogues.text: Yes. You have arthritis in your knee.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Is arthritis a catch-all for some kind of injury to the --

dialogues.speaker: DR. NAGATO
dialogues.text: No, arthritis is a degradation of the joints.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I know what traditional arthritis is.

dialogues.speaker: DR. NAGATO
dialogues.text: I’m not sure what you mean by “traditional,” but this is arthritis.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Arthritis arthritis?

dialogues.speaker: DR. NAGATO
dialogues.text: Yes, I usually just say it once.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: At my age?  Blue (09/16/2013) 39.

dialogues.speaker: DR. NAGATO
dialogues.text: You're what, 42?

dialogues.speaker: DR. NAGATO
dialogues.text: Well, it happens at 42 and it happens at 44,

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Uh huh.

dialogues.speaker: DR. NAGATO
dialogues.text: I’m going to get you a prescription for Paracetamol. We’1ll start there and see how it progresses, okay? He hands a prescription sheet to Josh. Josh holds it abou foot away and squints.

dialogues.speaker: DR. NAGATO
dialogues.text: Have you had your eyes checked recently?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I have genetically great eyes.

dialogues.speaker: DR. NAGATO
dialogues.text: (shrugs) You're growing up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We start on Jamie yawning open mouthed. We MOVE out to fi Josh in black rimmed glasses and his porkpie hat talking across the table from him.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: It’s weird...you know, I’m at that age where the things you think are only going to happen when you get older are actually happening.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: If I’m going to be totally honest with myself, I don’t think I’m ever going to die. I know that’s crazy.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: It’s crazy.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: I think I’m pathologically happy.  Blue (09/16/2013) 40.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (hesitates) I mean, Cornelia and I...for a while the fact that we got married was so amazing...I mean, we were married! Now we're just married, you know? Did you feel that way?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Best decision I ever made.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (glancing around) I really like this place.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: (excited) Oh, hey, I got my first response on Facebook.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: This guy, Kent Arlington. I haven’t seen him since highschool in Santa Cruz.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Did you flesh it out more, the idea?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: A little, yeah. He’s living in Poughkeepsie. Tipper and I will train it up there and find him. A shaggy white haired man, late 60’s, in a jean jacket an jeans enters the restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Shit.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: My father-in-law. Jamie yanks his head around.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Where?  41. Breitbart sees Josh and gives a tired smile. He approache Josh half-rises to shake his hand.

dialogues.speaker: BREITBART
dialogues.text: How are you?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Good, Leslie, you?

dialogues.speaker: BREITBART
dialogues.text: Good. Gearing up for my memorial.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (to Jamie) Leslie is having a tribute at Lincoln Center next month. (to Leslie) What are you doing here? How do you even know about this place?

dialogues.speaker: BREITBART
dialogues.text: Are you kidding? I’ve been coming here for the speck since it opened.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: This is Jamie, a friend of mine. Jamie stands up and shakes Breitbart’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: I’m sure you hear this all the time, but both “Wedding” and “Giving Arlo a Bath” changed my life. It made me want to tell stories in a non-fiction mode.

dialogues.speaker: BREITBART
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Thank you for your films.

dialogues.speaker: BREITBART
dialogues.text: (to Josh) How are the grandkids?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Still don’t exist.

dialogues.speaker: BREITBART
dialogues.text: You'll never regret it. (beat) How’s my daughter?  Uh... Blue (09/16/2013) 42.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: How does she seem to you?

dialogues.speaker: BREITBART
dialogues.text: I think she seems well.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: So, why are you asking me?

dialogues.speaker: BREITBART
dialogues.text: Cornelia says you're looking for finishing money.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Um...maybe...it depends on this grant, if this guy leaves his wife or not...

dialogues.speaker: BREITBART
dialogues.text: I met a guy, hedge fund or something or other, he’s looking to put money in docs. I’1l arrange a meeting if you're interested.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH BREITBART
dialogues.text: Don’t be proud, Josh. I'11 call you tomorrow with his number.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (defeated) Okay.

dialogues.speaker: BREITBART
dialogues.text: (to Jamie) Nice to meet you. He walks to another table in the back and is greeted by another man in a suit.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Jeez Louise, working with him must’ve been astonishing.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: It’s complicated, I felt I was seen as his protege and...I married his daughter, I needed to establish my own voice. I think he thought I rejected him, that I was arrogant. Maybe I was. Jamie yawns and texts.  Blue (09/16/2013) 43.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: But you’1ll take that meeting --

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Probably not.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: You have to, Yosh. I mean, money’s money, right?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Yeah, but I never pitch...I just don’t think in sound-bites... (musing) I understand we’re a culture of sound- bites, but --

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: (interrupting) I‘1l help you. You know, make it sound beautiful -- it is beautiful -- but beautiful to some suit.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Maybe. Josh looks over at Breitbart chatting with his lunch companion.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: You can totally say No to this, but would you have any interest in co- directing with me?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Oh... No, it’s your thing, it should be your thing.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: (quickly) I totally get it, yeah --

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (hesitates) Yeah...it should be your thing. Josh puts his hand on the check.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I got it.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Cool.  28
Josh still anticipates some resistance or more appreciati something, but gets nothing. He hesitates then throws dow cash.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Shall we go?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: You go ahead, I gotta take a leak. They embrace. We MOVE with Josh to the door. Something occurs to him. He turns around -- Jamie's at Breitbart’s table. He gestures animatedly. Breitbart laughs heartily. Josh watches. Finally, he turn and exits. INT. JOSH AND CORNELIA’S APARTMENT. DAY 28 Josh is laying random white items of clothing on the bed. Cornelia practices a hip hop routine.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: He just offered it to me like it was nothing. I’ve been trained to hoard credit, these kids are so generous.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Yeah. What do you mean, you know? Which part?

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: About credit. My dad always said that about you. You don’t collaborate well.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: He “always” said that? What's “always?”

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: I don’t know, twice. I wanted to do that thing about the public school in the Bronx and you were really excited about it until I suggested we do it together and then you kind of dropped it. Josh is about to defend himself. He hesitates.  29 Pink (09/30/2013)

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Maybe we should have done it. We still could.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: The time has past.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I’m sorry about that. I want to be better about that stuff.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: (hesitates, touched) Thanks. Cornelia’s phone rings. She dances over to it. her.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: What is that, a hoe-down?

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: No! It’s hip-hop. Cornelia finds her phone.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hey Fox! INT. FLETCHER AND MARINA’S APARTMENT. INTERCUT Marina nurses the baby.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: Fox! Do you guys want to come to the Connecticut house this weekend? Josh starts hip hop dancing with Cornelia.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: (laughing) Connecticut this weekend?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (loud whisper) No, we have the ayawasca. Fletcher walks by in the background. 45. Josh regards 29

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER MARINA
dialogues.text: Where’s the cardboard sleeve What’s on it? for this Wilco CD?  30 Pink (09/30/2013) 46.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER MARINA
dialogues.text: The same image that’s on the Why do you need it? The CD cD. is right here.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER MARINA
dialogues.text: I don’t know. It makes it It‘’ll be us and Pepper and special. her husband Reade and Elise and Dwight. And then Willow, Oscar and Peter who they’re calling Nemo.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: That’s a lot of people.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: Well, the last three are infants. Josh shakes his head, No and dances more vehemently.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: (trying not to laugh) Oh...you know... Actually, we’re doing this ayawasca ceremony with Jamie and Darby.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: What’s an ayawasca ceremony?

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: I guess...there’s a shaman and you drink this sludgy liquid made from a Peruvian root and you hallucinate and vomit up your demons.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: Oh... Okay. We’re just having a cookout and maybe playing charades SO...

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: It sounds great. Just bad timing. Josh and Cornelia are both laughing now and doing some combination of hip-hop/hoe-down.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: (clearly disappointed) Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A circle of kneeling people all dressed in white. It’s whatever white they had available at home so it’s mismatc  47. A tall thin guy, 30’s, with pale skin and long black hair kneels at a make-shift shrine. This is the shaman. In fro of him is an altar decorated with crystals and laminated cards of St. Francis, Gandhi, Merlin, King Tut. Josh leans over to Cornelia:

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: How did King Tut become magical all of a sudden? Jamie, in a white Puma track-suit, leans forward over a couple of people on Josh’s other side.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: It’s because they discovered his tomb in the occult boom of the 20's. “Shhh!” from the group. The shaman pops open what looks like a Coke bottle and po a brown sludgy liquid into a shot glass. He says a benediction. People, in succession, crawl over to him, he does a blessing of sorts on their forehead and hands them glass. They drink and return to their original spots. We watch as Jamie, Darby, Cornelia and Josh drink the dar sludge. Jamie drinks without thought. Darby does the quotes thing in the air before she drinks.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: This is our twenties!

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: I’m forty-one. Cornelia sips it. She looks up at the shaman who smiles encouragingly. She downs it and hands it back to him proudly. Josh hesitates, looks back at the group. He shrugs and do it, a significant portion missing his mouth. He quickly wipes at his chin and tries to get the spillage back into mouth. He licks his fingers and palm and the sides of the glass then hands the glass back to the shaman, who looks mildly irritated. They're back in their circle. The woman next to Josh whispers:  48.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Supposedly everyone sees Egyptian imagery.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Oh yeah?

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: I want to clear some father issues. You?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Oh, I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: It’s good to have a focus.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (thinks about it) Fear of death? You know, linear time not being such a big deal. The lights are lowered. The shaman’s assistant clears the air with an eagle feather.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (whispers) What’s the bucket for?

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Puking. People “shhh” Josh. The shaman goes around the room and makes a cross on everyone’s forehead. Josh closes his eye The FOLLOWING is in choppy, almost impressionistic images People start to trip. Darby gets up and joins a couple wh is dancing.

dialogues.speaker: SHAMAN
dialogues.text: We are purging dark energies, past pain. He plays some bongos and shakes a shaker.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: (under her breath) This shaman is kind of a d-bag. The woman next to Josh grabs a bucket and pukes.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: That’s my bucket.  49.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: I’m puking out your shit! Josh crawls next to Cornelia.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I feel it! Oh my God, I see a fucking pyramid. And a sphinx. It’s true, you see Egyptian shit. Honey, what are you seeing?

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: I’m in a deli in Bensonhurst.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: The serpent, Apep is speaking to me. He’s saying, go to the cattle of Ra. The Celestial Cow is waiting.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: I’m purchasing a bag of Sun Chips. CUT TO: Jamie stands with the shaman.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: I don’t believe in any state supported art. I think you need to just do it yourself. He vomits.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: (gargling vomit) I voted for Romney. Everyone vomits. We see this in succession.

dialogues.speaker: SHAMAN
dialogues.text: Watch the carpet! CUT TO: Josh opens his eyes. The room is a blur -- white figures drifting past. Josh gets up. Cornelia talks with the shaman in a corner. Josh waves he over madly. She excuses herself.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Maybe don’t flirt with the shaman.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: He was telling me about his boat. Cornelia grows quiet. Her eyes are glazed.  50.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: I wish you’d look at me the way you look at Jamie and Darby.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I look at you that way...

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: No, you don’t. You used to. When we first met you were like you are with them, you wooed me with romantic emails...

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: There’s no point in us emailing now...we’re in the same room all of the time.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: (hesitates) I don’t want to take away your enthusiasm for Jamie and Darby, I’m glad you like them so much...I just wish I could feel that energy from you once in a while. CUT TO: Darby leans her head against the wall. She talks the man next to her.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: I was falling asleep today on the L train and you know how your brain gets in these loops? I couldn’t remember the shape of a pineapple: “Are they like pears?” No, they’re like footballs with the ends cut off. It’s hard to call to mind the shapes of things. Do you find that? She vomits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cornelia wanders into a dark room. She sees Josh coming toward her.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: Josh, I’m sorry.  32 51. She embraces him. He holds her. They rock side to side. Cornelia kisses Josh on the mouth, long and passionate. S hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: You taste different. Cornelia pulls back.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: Josh?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: It’s me.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: Jamie, shit. I thought you were Josh. I’m so fucked up. I’m sorry. She puts her head on his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: Ugh, how embarrassing.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: It’s okay, worm. She looks up at him and they kiss again. She stops.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: Let’s never do that again. She walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josh drifts down a hallway. His eyes blinded by drifting geometric shapes and figures.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: It stopped working. Cornelia, mine stopped working anymore! But Cornelia isn’t there. He slips and rights himself wit the wall.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Nothing is happening. He trips and hits the floor with a thud. Jamie is picking Josh up --  Blue (09/16/2013)

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: How you doing, Yosh?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Is yours working? Mine isn’t working.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Mine’s working.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: What if I don’t find anything out? 52. He looks at Jamie, tears rolling down his face. He now se that Jamie is filming him.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Just roll with it. You’re going to be fine, see.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Thanks, Jamie. You’re so kind. And so generous. I’m so proud and selfish. I want to be generous like you. I want to help you with your film. I'11 come with you to film the guy. I don’t want credit or anything, just to help out.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Thanks Joshy, that’s beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Before we met, the only two feelings I had left were...wistful and disdainful. And being around you...I see what’s possible again. Is that corny?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: It’s goddamn corny, Joshy.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Yeah, I guess it is. I’m a cornball. (pause) I've felt like a failure for years. I wish Cornelia and I had had kids.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: It’s not too late, is it? Josh vomits. Jamie holds his head while he retches.  33 Blue (09/16/2013) 53.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: No problem, Jussle. Jamie vomits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cornelia sits on the stairs. She looks exhausted. People the street are starting their day, taking kids out, movin cars. Josh sits

dialogues.speaker: JOSH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It’s still tonight for us, but it’s tomorrow for everyone else. beside her. He looks tired, pale, worse for wear.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Let’s have kids! Or a kid. Something.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: Did the Celestial Cow tell you this?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (pause) Yeah, but that doesn’t make it any less true. Cornelia picks at the dry skin on her lip.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (re: the houses and pedestrians) All these people have babies -- what’s the big deal?

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: I thought we'd decided... I don’t want this to be every time you take a hallucinogen you want to have a baby.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Not every time.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: We missed our chance. I missed my chance. I’m fine with that.  34 35 Pink (09/30/2013) 54.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (pause) The serpent suggested we could adopt.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: He didn’t tell me that.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: You don’t want to? She slowly shakes her head. Pause. Josh notices something

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Is that the shaman’s Vespa? INT. FLETCHER/MARINA’S BUILDING - ELEVATOR. EVE 34 Josh and Cornelia, dressed casually. She holds a couple o take-out bags. Another couple, dressed up, stands next to them holding a bag with a ribbon.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: He’s been cooped up at home with a baby, and she loves these soup dumplings. This will be a great surprise.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I haven’t spoken to Fletcher for a while. I think he’s exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: (laughs) We'll probably be waking them up! The doors open. Both couples exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josh and Cornelia approach the apartment. Josh starts to clock the other couple walking right next to them. They a reach an apartment door. Voices and music from inside. Cornelia frowns. Josh rings He looks at the other couple who smile. Marina opens the door in a party dress, beaming and holdi white wine. Party guests mingle behind her.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: (horrified) Cornelia...Josh. (welcoming) Gaby, Mike!

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: COUPLE
dialogues.text: You look amazing! The other couple enters the party. Fletcher appears in th background loudly bantering with another guy.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: -+-I know! I felt like I was in one of those sci-fi movies where everyone is ranked by intellect -- His face drops when he sees Josh and Cornelia.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: Oh...fucking shit... He and Marina come out into the hallway, the door ajar be them.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: Did we...I guess you’re having a thing.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: Uh...yeah. We... God, this is embarrassing.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: Is it a baby thing or...?

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: No, actually...Willow’s at my mother’s.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: Oh...

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: We weren’t invited.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: Well...we didn’t think...

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: Oh, God, I don’t know what to say... Another couple appears behind Josh and Cornelia.

dialogues.speaker: COUPLE
dialogues.text: Hey, girly girl. You look fiiiine!  Pink (09/30/2013) They kiss and hand Marina a wrapped gift.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Hey Cornelia, how are you?

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: Fine, Grace, you?

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Great.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: (to the other couple) Come inside, there’s a full bar -- The other couple enters the apartment.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: What is going on?

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: I’m sorry...we didn’t think you'd want to come or...

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: Well, for one thing these are people our own age.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: Oh, come on!

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: And maybe you have a titseeka ceremony or something.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Ayawasca! It was therapeutic. I learned some shit. I think Cornelia did too.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: (awkwardly) I did too. Learn some shit.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: You guys were wacked out on Peruvian mescallen, of course you’re going to learn some shit. I went under during a colonoscopy last week and I learned some shit. 56.  Pink (09/30/2013) 57.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Don’t patronize us, man.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: Listen, we don’t know how else to say this, but...we’re worried about you guys.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: Yeah, you know...I mean, it’s cool you don’t want to have kids --

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: Don’t make this about the baby cult, Marina. Okay? I don’t appreciate * that kind of superior attitude. It’s really ugly.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: That’s not what I’m saying! I can’t help it if I want you to have kids.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: We think you guys would really benefit from it. That’s all.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: (suddenly emotional) But you don’t realize how inappropriate it is to say it like you say it. Not everyone wants a baby! Not everyone can have one all the time!

dialogues.speaker: COUPLE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hi sexy lady! Yet another couple, Elise and her husband, arrives, kisse Marina and Fletcher. *

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: (smiling hostess) Elise! Come in! Come in! They enter. Marina brings her voice down: *

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: Since we've had the baby, I feel you pulling away, Cornelia. I just do.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA FLETCHER
dialogues.text: I went to a fucking baby (to Josh) music class with you! Do you What’s with the hat? know how humiliating that is?  36 37 Pink (09/30/2013) 58.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER MARINA
dialogues.text: You look like assholes we Why is it humiliating? This went to highschool with who is my life now! would cruise by the prom but not go in.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: (getting emotional) It can be very isolating and lonely when you have a kid.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: (re: the crowd inside) Yeah, I can tell.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: We’re old men, Josh.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH FLETCHER
dialogues.text: Speak for yourself. You're an old man with a hat.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: (sadly) Let’s go, Josh.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: Stay, you’re here...come in.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (emphatic) There is no way we’re coming in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside the APARTMENT. Josh and Cornelia sit alone by the window. People are laughing, talking loudly. Cornelia dow her wine in one. Josh looks furious.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (sings) “You're playing Nintendo.” INT. JAMIE’S CAR. DAY 37 Jamie drives, Josh next to him. Cornelia, Darby and Tippe who wears a T-shirt that reads: Some Crappy Band, are squeezed in the back. Jamie sings and Tipper responds:  59.

dialogues.speaker: TIPPER
dialogues.text: (sings) “That's not what I’m doing, that’s not what I’m doing.”

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE TIPPER
dialogues.text: “You're surfing the web.” “That's not what I’m doing, that’s not what I’m doing.”

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE TIPPER
dialogues.text: “You're crying your eyes “That's not what I’m doing, out.” that’s not what I’m doing.”

dialogues.speaker: TIPPER
dialogues.text: (she beats the back of Josh's seat three times) “I’m making a sandwich!” Both of them, flush and beaming look around the car.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Nice.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: (trying to be positive) Fun. Darby grumbles. She turns to Cornelia.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: Connecticut has the best thrifting. He'll drop us off before they do their filming.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Tipper and I started a band called Cookie O’Puss. Have you seen that on YouTube?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
