dialogues.text: (a bit annoyed) That was a commercial when I was a kid.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: It’s fucking hilarious.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (trying to own it) I know, we used to always do his voice.

dialogues.speaker: TIPPER
dialogues.text: “My name is Cookie O’Puss!”  38 39 60.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (trying to do it first) “My name is Cookie O’Puss.”

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE JOSH
dialogues.text: “My name is Cookie O’Puss.” Right.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: It’s the name of our band.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josh films Jamie as he gets out of the car. Tipper films house.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: He was this kind of amazing combination of jock and brain and he could sing, he was in the acapella group called the Night Owls. I mean kind of the perfect guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three of them wait at the door. Tipper films. Jamie knocks. A skinny woman in her 30's appears.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Hey, I called, my name’s Jamie, I'ma friend of Kent's.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER
dialogues.text: Kent isn’t here.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Oh...well, will he be back soon? She shakes her head. She looks over at Tipper who’s filmi

dialogues.speaker: SISTER
dialogues.text: What’s --

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: We went to school together. It’s been a while, but he contacted me recently on Facebook. It would mean a lot to me if I could see him. The sister hesitates. She’s debating something in her hea  40 4l 61.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamie, Josh and Tipper are led by an orderly down a long sterile hallway. They reach a set of automatic doors. A loud buzz. They go through the doors to another set of doors. Anothe loud buzz. They open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kent, 20's, pale and thin, lies in bed watching a cooking show. He’s eating ice cream out of a container. Jamie, Tipper and Josh enter. He looks up as they approach, plac the ice cream on the bed-side table. CUT TO: Josh shoots Jamie. Tipper shoots Kent. Kent sits in bed, he talks somberly. Jamie sits at his bed-side.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: A ceramic platter didn’t break and accidentally cut both my wrists.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: No?

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: No. I’ve been unhappy. I did it to myself. I cut my wrists.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: You broke a ceramic platter and used the shards to cut your wrists? Josh starts to say something, he knows where Kent’s going with this, but he holds himself back.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: No, there was no ceramic platter. I mean, there is, I had one in mind when I was telling the story.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: But the shards were from the platter?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (can’t help himself) What Kent is saying is he imagined an actual platter to make his story feel more authentic, but really he just cut his wrists with what, probably a razor blade? Kent and Jamie look over at Josh. Kent looks annoyed.  Blue (09/16/2013) 62.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: (to Jamie) Who is he? CUT TO: Jamie leans in. Kent seems emotional.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: You were the guy, you know. You were beautiful. I mean you dated Jenny Pepperdine! Kent flashes a weary smile.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: You know I bought a necklace like the one you used to wear --

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: My puka shells?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. You know, I was going through a tough time in highschool, my mom was really sick with ovarian cancer, I was pretty promiscuous, but I couldn’t love anyone, I had body issues -- We slowly ZOOM in on Jamie as he talks. Josh's closed eye opens. While keeping the camera trained Jamie, he inspects it, bewildered. He’s not pressing anything. He sees -- Jamie holds a small remote in his hand. He’s zooming in o himself.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: You had written a poem for English, you were this athlete and you wrote this beautiful poem. Do you know what poem I’m talking about?

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: I wrote a lot of poems.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: It was a line, very simple, but effective, “I want to be unbridgeable.” That one line got me through my mother’s illness.  Blue (09/16/2013) 63.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Yeah? I don’t know why I stopped writing poetry. I stopped doing a lot of things. Why do we stop doing things? I guess life happens.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Life is other plans.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (from behind the camera) Life is what happens when you're making other plans. Jamie and Kent both startle and turn to the camera.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: (again annoyed) Who is he?

dialogues.speaker: DARBY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I keep trying to get people to agree with me on this: I hate Tipper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Antiques and vintage clothing. Darby helps Cornelia lace a corset.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: She ends every word she can with “ish.” I thought she was making fun of this way of talking until it was clear that she wasn’t.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: She tries too hard.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: Exactly! But it’s low-key so you don’t notice it. I shouldn’t shit- talk Tipper. I have so many things.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: You and Jamie were highschool sweethearts?

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: No, Jamie was only in Santa Cruz for a semester. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: DARBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: His dad worked for a medical supply company that was contracted by the army and they were never in one place very long. Jamie can be at home anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: Josh is only at home at home.  43 64. The corset is laced. Cornelia turns and looks at herself the mirror. She’s horrified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The four of them and Tipper in a booth. Jamie and Tipper have just finished telling Darby and Cornelia about the d Josh is looking at something on his phone.

dialogues.speaker: TIPPER
dialogues.text: He was soulful-ish, you know.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Sister, that’s an understatement. You can tell he’s been to some dark places.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: (petulant) We went to some dark places too. I bought a dress. Cornelia didn’t buy a corset.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: (eating) Mm, this burger is in-cred-ible.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (re: his phone) Holy shit.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: What’s wrong?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: No...nothing...I just Googled Kent... (looks up to Jamie) Did you Google him?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: No, I wanted it to be fresh.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: This...it’s there’s a picture, it’s the same guy. He was in Afghanistan.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: (surprised) Really?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Yeah...he...this article says he was part of a massacre in Wanat. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: JOSH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They opened fire on a bus full of civilians... He then spoke out publicly about it and then he refused to fight. He was jailed briefly then he returned to battle, was injured and given the Purple Heart.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: You're kidding? Josh hands Jamie his phone. Jamie beams.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: It says two men in his unit have killed themselves. Tipper -- Tipper gets out the camera and turns it on Josh. Josh loo into the lens strangely.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Do it again, what you did.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Which part?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: The phone, the discovery, everything.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Oh... Josh awkwardly looks at his phone then back up. The four them are waiting.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (stilted) It’s the same guy... Is that what I said? How did I say it? Jamie yawns, impatiently. Josh tries again:

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (acting now) It’s the same guy! Holy shit. Jamie, take a look at this. Tipper swings the camera at Jamie. He grabs Josh’s phone reacts almost identically.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: It says two men in his unit have killed themselves.  66.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (excited, getting the hang of it) We have to go back!

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: We have to get him talking about this. This is the movie! Now it’s not just some stupid Facebook thing. Jamie looks at Josh oddly. Josh backtracks:

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Not that that wasn’t a good idea too. But, and I hate this expression, but you stepped in shit! (suddenly) Cornelia!

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: (caught off guard) What?! Josh kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I don’t know! Jamie digs into his food.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Thank God I’ve got you, Joshy! We did what you said: we didn’t know the answers, we discovered it. I should get a good book on Afghanistan. And war in general. I really know so little about it.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (decides to go for it) You know who you should talk to. Ira Mandelstam, the guy in my film he could tell you a lot about war and the politics of war.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: That’s your guy, though, Joshy. I can’t take your guy.  44 45 Blue (09/16/2013) 67.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I don’t care. I want to share him with you. (to the table) Look ma, I’m sharing!

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Jeez Louise, that would be fucking beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: (suddenly, caught up in the whole thing) You know, if you want help... I could help or...produce this for you... Josh looks at Cornelia, surprised. He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: My dad’s between things now...

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Oh, my God. Are you kidding, I'd be so pumped. Thank you, thank you. Josh keeps smiling. He wants very badly for this to feel good. INT. SCHOLAR’S APARTMENT 44 Ira, the scholar, is talking about the power structure of United States. Jamie shoots him. Tipper holds a boom. She wears a T-shirt that reads in generic lettering: A Colleg Didn't Go To. Cornelia stands close by. Josh sits ina chair in the back, listening through headphones. His eyes drift away from the scholar and turn inward. He looks alm afraid. INT. SCHOLAR’S BEDROOM 45 A mess of books and clothes and dogs and dog beds. Josh pulls Cornelia inside and shuts the door.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (hushed) Can I say something I’m ashamed of?

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s not generous. And I probably don't really mean it.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: Okay. Go.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: And I think Jamie’s great so --

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: Say it!

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (snapping) I can’t fucking believe his idiotic Facebook idea paid off! It’s so fucking stupid! And my thing is a mess. A total fucking mess. (pause) Sorry, I feel bad saying that. But I also hate the fact he’s calling his band Cookie O’Puss.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: What’s wrong with that?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: It’s just some funny old kitschy thing to him he saw on YouTube. But that was my commercial. I actually experienced it. You know?

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: I don’t know from Cookie Puss.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Really? It was for Carvel. Cookie Puss was the original one but they did an ice cream cake for Saint Patrick’s Day and it was this floating green Irish cake that said, “My name is Cookie O’Puss.” Cornelia is silent.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (exhales) I’m being ridiculous. I probably don’t mean any of it.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: My dad likes to say, “The more, the more.” 68.  46

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: That’s because your dad has everything. And then he gets more. (off her look) No, he’s right. There’s enough to go around for everyone.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Yo, Yosh! You got a pitch you got to attend! She kisses him.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: Good luck.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. FINANCIAL DISTRICT. DAY
dialogues.text: Jamie walks with Josh through stopped traffic toward the Goldman Sachs building.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Remember, ask him questions. You're interviewing him. He’d be goddamn lucky to invest in your film.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: And talk about shit he understands, see. Short and to the point. A bike messenger swerves by them on the sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: (suddenly furious) Ride on the street, man! (and then back to Josh not missing a beat) Psych him up. Talk about money. Talk about war. Power. Race. Make it relevant to him.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Be yourself, everyone else is taken. Jamie straightens Josh's jacket collar.  47 Blue (09/16/2013) 70.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Ira was beautiful today. I’m gonna have a screening of the cut footage at the apartment on Friday.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: You cut it already? We just shot it two days ago.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: I know. I was up all night. (patting Josh on the back) We'll be okay, Joshy. Don’t you fret.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Maybe take a day or two to make sure you like it.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Or I can take ten years. Josh hesitates, taken aback. Jamie laughs.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: I'm fucking with you, Joshy. Your thing is going to be totally brilliant. They reach the doorway of the office building. Jamie take the big headphones from around his neck and puts them on Josh. Jamie presses Play. “Eye of The Tiger” by Survivor.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I remember when this song was just considered bad! But it’s working.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Remember, he’s lucky to have this opportunity. You're friggin’ Josh Srebnick.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: My name sounds so much better when you say it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josh shakes hands with a bulky fratty looking hedge fund 30’s, in a suit. This is Dave. Josh sits on a couch, Dave in an armchair. Dave drinks fr a highball glass.  71.

dialogues.speaker: HEDGE FUND DAVE
dialogues.text: You see Mad Men?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: HEDGE FUND DAVE
dialogues.text: (waves it off) It’s really apple juice. Nah, it’s whiskey. Nah, it’s not. It is. He drinks.

dialogues.speaker: HEDGE FUND DAVE
dialogues.text: So, tell me more about your project.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Well, maybe a good way to start is by asking you a question.

dialogues.speaker: HEDGE FUND DAVE
dialogues.text: Hey, they were all raped when I got there. Josh stares at him blankly.

dialogues.speaker: HEDGE FUND DAVE
dialogues.text: (re: highball) This is my second in twenty minutes. Shoot.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Do you know the percentage of African American adult males currently in jail?

dialogues.speaker: HEDGE FUND DAVE
dialogues.text: I don't.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Take a guess.

dialogues.speaker: HEDGE FUND DAVE
dialogues.text: (playing along but not really thinking) Like 60%?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Jesus, no! (pause) It's over 9%. That's nearly 1 in 10 African American adult males, nearly a million and half.  72.

dialogues.speaker: HEDGE FUND DAVE
dialogues.text: A million and a half is a lot.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: It's insane, but people don't realize this. They think because we have a black president...

dialogues.speaker: HEDGE FUND DAVE
dialogues.text: (as if he's helping Josh out) So this is about prison. Like a black Shawshank. But real. A real, black Shawshank.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (thrown) No, not...no. (pause and then speaking quickly) There's a section, an Entr'acte really, on the function of race in the prison industrial complex... (trying to get back on track) But the film is really about how power in America works... Do you know the historian, Ira Mandelstam?

dialogues.speaker: HEDGE FUND DAVE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (pleased) Really?

dialogues.speaker: HEDGE FUND DAVE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Well, we have over a hundred hours of interviews with him. Now --

dialogues.speaker: HEDGE FUND DAVE
dialogues.text: The movie’s a hundred hours?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: No, we'll cut it. Now, this guy, he’s not particularly charismatic, he’s kind of anti-social, maybe asbergers, but not interesting asbergers. He’s kind of boring even. But he’s a charismatic thinker.  73.

dialogues.speaker: HEDGE FUND DAVE
dialogues.text: How do you show what he thinks? Cartoons?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (what?!) No, not cartoons. He says it.

dialogues.speaker: HEDGE FUND DAVE
dialogues.text: But he’s boring.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Well...yes, but like many boring things, the longer you watch it, it takes on a different dimension -- Josh wipes the sweat that has now accumulated on his face Dave's glance goes to his Blackberry. He types something quickly.

dialogues.speaker: HEDGE FUND DAVE
dialogues.text: Mmm hmm. So, what’s it about?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: It’s really a very simple idea. The three sections correspond to the three nodes of what Mills called the power elite: the political, military and economic. But, and this is key, each part has to interconnect to show how none of these three nodes functions without the other. Dave tries to surreptitiously glance at his Blackberry.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: It’s a linear film of course, but I imagine it as a kind of hypertext. To be clear, the film is really about the working class and, I can’t speak on behalf of the working class. I can't make their film, of course. They have to be felt as the impossible subject of the text. Through an examination of the power structure the voice of the working class has to be revealed in the margins through its very absence. If that makes sense. The phone rings. Both Dave and Josh look at it.

dialogues.speaker: HEDGE FUND DAVE
dialogues.text: Hey, I’m suddenly so popular.  48 49 74.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (barrels on) But it’s not even really about the power structure but about what it means to make a film about it. It’s about the very possibility of making this film...It’s really about America. Dave can’t help it. He lunges for the phone. The sound of KNOCKING. INT. BREITBART’S APARTMENT - DOORWAY. DAY 48 Josh stands in the doorway, he wears his bike helmet and holds his hat. Breitbart smiles.

dialogues.speaker: BREITBART
dialogues.text: I was just working on my speech for my memorial. What’s on your mind, son? Josh nervously unstraps his bike helmet and puts on his h An awkward exchange as he has trouble holding both. He exhales. Breitbart finally accommodates by taking the hel

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Would you watch what I have? I think I’m at a point where I need a new set of eyes.

dialogues.speaker: BREITBART
dialogues.text: Ten years with the same project will do that to you.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: BREITBART
dialogues.text: (warmly) Of course I’1l watch it. Come in, son.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. BREITBART’S APARTMENT - LIVING ROOM/KITCHEN. DAY 49 They watch the scholar on Breitbart’s new TV. Josh can’t look at the screen, his eyes on are Breitbart. CUT TO: Josh, still watching Breitbart. The movie ends. Breitbart nods, shuts off the TV with a remote.

dialogues.speaker: BREITBART
dialogues.text: I just got this TV. It’s a smart TV.  75. He gets up and stretches, clearly very stiff from sitting so long.

dialogues.speaker: BREITBART
dialogues.text: I’1l put a kettle on. You want some tea?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Okay. Breitbart goes to his kitchen. Josh waits, impatiently.

dialogues.speaker: BREITBART, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Well, you have a lot of good material there.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Uh huh.

dialogues.speaker: BREITBART, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Lots to think about. I need to process it.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Uh huh. Breitbart reappears in the kitchen doorway.

dialogues.speaker: BREITBART
dialogues.text: Do you need the stuff about Turkish politics?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Yes, because it connects to what he’s saying about the shift in power in the contemporary global economy. And, of course, it relates back to the earlier stuff on the Ottoman Empire.

dialogues.speaker: BREITBART
dialogues.text: Right, but it feels like a detour. What about the lengthy history of the Triangle Shirtwaste Factory Fire? Do you need that?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: The interview with Tillie Kupferschmidst’s great great niece? That’s the emotional center of the movie. That’s where things come together. Without that scene...why make the film at all?  76.

dialogues.speaker: BREITBART
dialogues.text: But it’s too long.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: It has to be long. The point is it makes you uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: BREITBART
dialogues.text: (gently) I wasn’t uncomfortable, I was bored. The kettle goes off. Breitbart goes back into the kitchen Josh follows him in.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Well, maybe boredom is your defense from the discomfort.

dialogues.speaker: BREITBART
dialogues.text: (growing impatient) You just showed me a six and a half hour movie that runs about seven hours too long. I’m trying to help.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I understand, I understand. I think I need to shoot some more interviews --

dialogues.speaker: BREITBART
dialogues.text: (quickly) Don’t shoot anymore! You have enough.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Yeah? I just don’t think you're getting it or maybe there’s something about me or what you saw that’s clouding your judgement.

dialogues.speaker: BREITBART
dialogues.text: I’m telling you what I really feel.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I don’t believe it. I think you’re being deliberately critical.

dialogues.speaker: BREITBART
dialogues.text: Josh, I’m trying to help you.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Bullshit! Is it because Cornelia and I didn’t have children?

dialogues.speaker: BREITBART
dialogues.text: Oh, come on, Josh.  77.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: We tried. There were miscarriages. I had to give her a shot in her ass every day for three months. It’s a huge fucking needle.

dialogues.speaker: BREITBART
dialogues.text: I didn’t know you tried so hard. She didn’t tell me. I thought you guys didn’t want kids.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: We didn’t want to hope for something we probably couldn’t have. (collecting his things) This was a mistake.

dialogues.speaker: BREITBART
dialogues.text: I’m sorry you feel that way. Josh starts for door.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I know you think I didn’t reach my potential.

dialogues.speaker: BREITBART
dialogues.text: No, son, no I don’t think you did. (beat) Your first film was so wonderful and entertaining. We recognized ourselves in it. This is ungenerous, it’s like you took your ball and went home.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: You know what? I’m sorry I didn’t become you.

dialogues.speaker: BREITBART
dialogues.text: I don’t want you to be me, Josh.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Yeah, right.

dialogues.speaker: BREITBART
dialogues.text: I‘1l see you at Thanksgiving.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I’m not going to eat another fucking fried turkey FYI.

dialogues.speaker: BREITBART
dialogues.text: Then make your own.  50 51 Blue (09/16/2013) Josh slams the door.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. WEST END AVENUE. DAY
dialogues.text: Josh walks up to a sign-post. His chain- severed in half. His bike is gone.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Fuck! EXT. HOUSING PROJECTS, BASKETBALL COURT. Jamie aggressively drives to the basket, a jump shot over a leaping defender. He teammates as they hurry back on defense. Josh watches through a chain link fence. 78. 50 link chain has been

dialogues.speaker: DAY 51
dialogues.text: pulls back and makes fist bumps his CUT TO: Jamie, sweating, sees Josh through the fence. He jogs over and they talk through the chain-link.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Yosh! How did you find me?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (sheepishly) There's like eight different ways to find out where you are on the internet. And also through people we both know.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Ha! You want to play?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Nah, I don’t have the right shoes. (pause) Hey, I was thinking...you know how you asked...maybe, if you’re still up for it, I will co-direct with you... Jamie hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: You know...if that’s still cool?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: I’m not sure, Yoshy, I’m...at this point, I’m kind of in it, you know?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (his face turning red) Uh huh.  Blue (09/16/2013) 78A.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: I mean, I’m kind of into doing it all now... I mean...you know?  52 79.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Uh huh.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: I better get back to the game. I’11 see you tonight, yeah?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (quickly) Yeah. INT. JAMIE AND DARBY’S APARTMENT, BUSHWICK. DAY 52 Josh enters -- he’s late. The space is packed -- mostly w a sea of 20-something kids who lie on top of each other o the floor watching Jamie’s movie. Tipper, dressed up ina sort of Mary Jane outfit and horn-rimmed glasses, perched on a table, watching very seriously, her arms wrapped aro her long bent legs. Jamie stands in back, he looks nervou Darby a few feet away from him is texting. Cornelia waves from a crowded corner. Josh smiles wearily. Kent talks soberly on screen.

dialogues.speaker: KENT, (ON SCREEN)
dialogues.text: In the report it says we followed procedure. A flashlight, three flares, and the hand signals... A quick jerky zoom into Kent, missing his face and then adjusting to find him. He does the hand signals, punctuat them with:

dialogues.speaker: KENT, (ON SCREEN)
dialogues.text: .---bum, bum, bum...but that’s not how I remember it. It was sheer fucking panic when the bus approached the convoy. We opened fire -- Josh moves closer, looking for a place to sit or stand. H steps over a couple lying on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: Ow. Those are my fingers.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Sorry, sorry. Josh stops in his tracks. Over on the side, the Moon Land headline above his head, stands Breitbart. To his right, hedge fund dude, Dave.  Blue (09/16/2013) 80. A light sweat breaks out on Josh’s face. Darby is looking straight at him. She gives him a sad smile. Josh looks ba at the screen. CLOSE: Josh’s scholar, Ira, talking about the politics of war. CUT TO: The movie is over. The mostly 20-something crowd laughs, drinks beers. Breitbart picks an Oreo from a bowl Oreos on a table. Josh pushes through the kids to find Jamie.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Yoshy!

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: You invited Breitbart?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, he called me after you introduced us.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: He called you?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Yeah...and at our dinner I invited him to tonight.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: At “our dinner?” Dinner with him? When did you have dinner?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: After he called me, he suggested we get dinner.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Uh huh. (pause) Where'd you go?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: This beautiful joint, um, on the Upper West Side --

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Jackson Hole.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Yeah! How’d you know?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: That’s where he goes.  81.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Great burgers. Have you been there?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Yes, I’ve been there with hima million times.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Have you gotten the Buffalo burger?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Of course!

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: He dug the footage. (pause) Is something wrong?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I guess I wish you'd asked me before you just went to him...

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Hey, I’m sorry. I called him actually just to ask him a question about how he shot something and we just got to talking, see, and he asked me what I was working on...

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: So you called him?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: You said he called you.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: He called me back, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Does Cornelia know?

dialogues.speaker: HEDGE FUND DAVE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Very cool! Very cool. The hedge fund guy, Dave, does a double fist bump with Ja which they mime exploding.

dialogues.speaker: HEDGE FUND DAVE
dialogues.text: I’m proud to be part of it.  Blue (09/16/2013) 82.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Dave, you know Josh.

dialogues.speaker: HEDGE FUND DAVE
dialogues.text: (barely looking at Josh) Nice to meet you. (to Jamie) Seriously dude, this movie is kill- aaahhhh. (does a little dance) We're going to Afghanistan, we're going to Afghanistan...

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (taken aback) You're going to Afghanistan?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: To interview soldiers in Kent’s unit. We've got a butt-load of work to do before we go. I’m going to need help.

dialogues.speaker: HEDGE FUND DAVE
dialogues.text: Afghanistan, Afghanistan! Josh starts to retreat into the crowd. He hesitates. It pains him to say this, but:

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Um, if you have any other editing work, my guy Tim, is great and could use some cash.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: That would be beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (defeated) I‘1l text you his info.

dialogues.speaker: HEDGE FUND DAVE
dialogues.text: (to Jamie) Dude, I want you to meet Diane, she’s a reporter for the Times. Dave drags Jamie across the room. Darby takes Jamie’s arm he passes, she asks him a question. He replies tersely ba She walks away, pissed. Dave pulls Jamie onward. We MOVE in on Josh. Color vanishes from his face as a terrible sinking feeling enters his body. Two hands wrap around his neck like choking. He reacts.  83.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Ahh! It’s Cornelia. She smokes a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: I’ve been looking for you.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: You're smoking? (ve: everything) What’s going on? This is like a fucking bad dream. Everyone is here doing weird shit. Where’s my highschool algebra teacher, Mr. Morelli riding a fucking turtle? Across the room, Breitbart is approached by Dave and Jami

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: (re: her dad) I had no idea Dad was coming. I saw him when I got here.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Are you sure? Are you sure you’re not just saying that?

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: Yes, Josh! Why would I lie to you?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Do you think Jamie came to my talk because he knew I was married to you? That this was all so he could meet your dad?

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: Josh, you know, the world isn’t a conspiracy against you.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: You know, fuck you.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: Fuck you. Don’t talk to me like that.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I’m saying “Fuck you” in that way Jamie and Darby say it where it’s not a real Fuck you, it’s a semi-playful Fuck you.  84.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: We’re not Jamie and Darby. We don’t talk to each other that way. If you say Fuck you to me it feels like a real Fuck you.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: It is real.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: Fuck you. And not semi-playfully either!

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Fuck you. Total real, cutting to the core: Fuck you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josh comes outside, furious. Darby is making out with a Latino guy who looks like a gang member.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Darby? Darby lets go of the guy and looks at Josh.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: Hey, sir.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: Shit’s bad. (pause) You want to get some goat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josh and Darby eat at a table.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: Crushes fade. Things lose their luster, you know? Maybe I’m just down on relationships right now.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: What about Jamie?

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: Jamie’s in love with Jamie.  85.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I thought you guys seemed great.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: You know how no one will ever pick up just a male hitchhiker? But if it’s a couple, you might pull over? I’m the girl so you'll pull over and pick up Jamie. (pause) Doing ayawasca I realized I never forgave my mom for dying and until I do I’1l never have a decent relationship with a guy.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: When did she die?

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: When I was in highschool. She had ovarian cancer.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I’m sorry... (realizing) Isn’t that also how Jamie’s mom died? He talks about it in the film. Darby hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: Why’d you let Jamie use your scholar?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I was trying out being generous. He'd do the same for me. That’s how you guys are.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: (with sympathy) Oh, Josh... You’re such a man-fox.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: A man-fox? I wish it didn’t need the “man” qualifier?

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: Because you’re like a hot dad. Without children. Suddenly, she pulls her chair over to him, leans in, and kisses him on the mouth. He slowly moves away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We shouldn't... She slides her chair back to her side of the table. hesitates, embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: This is the part where I say, “I was a bet?!”

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: You know those romantic comedies where the girl was a bet? He nods. She nods too.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Just because they did, doesn’t mean we have to.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: What...what do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: She never told you? Jamie and Cornelia made out at the ayawasca. It was in the Papyrus reeds behind the pyramids. Josh looks staggered.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I stole one of Tipper’s adderalls. You want to go dancing?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (now getting angry) Yeah, I’m not going home tonight.
She 55 Darby dances with Josh amidst muscular shirtless gay men. throws himself into it, trying to lose himself completely

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Thanks for meeting me so early.

dialogues.speaker: INT. JACKSON HOLE RESTAURANT. MORNING
dialogues.text: 56 Jamie sits across from Cornelia. She looks tired and distracted.  87.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: We've got a butt-load to do. Dave needs a budget for Afghanistan.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: I’m almost finished with it.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: I’ve been reading a lot about Afghanistan. It’s crazy. You know no one’s ever been able to successfully occupy Afghanistan.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: (looking at her phone to see if anyone called) Yeah...I’ve heard that.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: I think we got something now. With your help, it can really be something. (pause) Leslie’s notes were awesome.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: He’s smart that way.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: And he’s really chill to kick it with. She hesitates, she wipes a tear from her chin.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. Josh and I had a fight last night and...he didn’t come home. Cornelia starts to cry. Jamie hands her a napkin.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Hey, hey, it’s going to be okay. Joshy will come back.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: (wipes her face) Thank you. I’m sorry I’m like this.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Hey, no worries. (his eyes avert her) I was thinking, maybe you and your dad would want to work on my thing together. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He seems to want to get involved. It might be kind of great, right? A moment, Cornelia studies him. Jamie inspects his fork.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: I mean, you’re producing, but he could bless it essentially...

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: Bless it? Like a sneeze?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: (smiles) I was thinking more like the Pope.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: He doesn’t do that kind of thing --

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: I think if you asked him, he might. Cornelia hesitates. She says, suddenly:

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: Did you ever see Power Elite? Jamie gets up and exchanges his fork with one on another table.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: What’s that? The corner of Cornelia’s mouth turns up.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: (catching himself) Josh's movie! Goddamn, yes. I told him that. I loved that scene with the dogs. Jamie returns with the new fork.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: When you went to Josh’s class, you knew Josh and I were married, didn’t you? And that Leslie was my dad.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: (hesitates) Hey, I admire lots of people, I want lots of things. You know what I mean. We all want stuff -- it doesn’t mean we’re douche bags. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're a hip chick. You kissed me, you're married to my friend, but I get it --

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: I thought you were Josh.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: The first time. Cornelia stiffens.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: You know, but out of context, if other people heard about it, it might be misconstrued. Cornelia looks out the window. Josh is across the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cornelia approaches Josh, he’s in the same clothes from l night. She’s furious.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: Where were you last night?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I went dancing with Darby at an after hours gay club. (angry and suspicious) Is this some kind of private meeting?

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: Did you follow me here?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I follow him on Twitter! You can’t lie like we used to lie anymore. Everything is reported. Nothing is private.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: There’s nothing going on --

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Don’t lie to me. You kissed him. I know all about it.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: I thought he was you, Joshy.  Blue (09/16/2013) 89A.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Don’t call me Joshy! You don’t call me Joshy.  90.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: It’s all a pose...it’s like he once saw a sincere person and has been imitating him ever since! And you’re falling for it.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: (shakes her head) I didn’t even like them! You convinced me how awesome they were.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: They're entitled little brats. And don’t you see, this is alla plan. He wants to destroy me. Jamie appears across the street, he holds a small video camera. He waves at Josh.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Go back inside! Josh takes off his porkpie hat.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: You and your father can have him. You always wanted a more successful me, so go for it.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: What is wrong with you?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I didn’t know when we got married that you also wanted to play kissy face with the twenty-five year olds. I didn’t know you wouldn’t want to have kids.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: I didn’t know it either. I didn’t know you'd never finish your movie.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I'll finish it! I want to get it right.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: It’s obsession. It’s fear. I don’t know. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s not really about making anything. At least Jamie makes something!

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Do NOT compare what I do with him.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: Why not? When you felt a part of it, you loved it. (Josh says nothing) And you use your career as an excuse not to do anything. We don’t make decisions, we don’t go on vacations, we don’t have kids.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I want a kid.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: You want it now that it’s impossible.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: It’s not impossible.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: No. It’s over. It’s done. I’m not putting myself through that anymore. (indicating her body) This is closed. Josh hesitates and then throws his hat into a garbage can He starts to walk away. He turns around, retrieves the ha from the garbage and walks away for real.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josh blows into an air mattress.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Marina’s at a work dinner. Fletcher enters with a couple of old looking sheets. Will the baby, sleeps in a moby wrapped around Fletcher’s tors

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: They’re both top-sheets but...you know...

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Thanks.  92.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: You might wake up when I come through here for Willow’s 2 AM feeding. And then 5 AM. And then all the other times she wakes up.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: That’s okay. Fletcher pours them both whiskeys. Josh picks up a cardbo sleeve from a Wilco CD off of a table. He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (re: the baby) How is she?

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: (looks down at her) Pretty good. Cool baby. To be honest, though, it’s a little hard for me to relate to an infant.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: It seems kind of cool though.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: It’s like the pregnancy is its own thing. You get so used to it. After a while I just felt, we did this, we don’t actually need the baby.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (nods ) I'm sorry if I’ve appeared crazy or...I don’t know...

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: I’m sorry we didn’t invite you to the party.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (shrugs) I think I’ve been jealous of you guys having a kid...

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: You know, before you have a kid, everyone tells you, “It’s the best thing you'll ever do.” As soon as you bring that baby back from the hospital, the same people say, “Don’t worry, it gets better.” It’s like, what the fuck was that all about before?  59

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Having Willow must have changed your whole perspective on life.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: (pause) Not as much as I hoped it would. (lowering his voice) I love my kid but I’m still the most important person in my life. Fletcher winces as he sits in a chair.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: Did I tell you I have a herniated disk, C5 or some shit... I’m getting an epidurol on Monday.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (laughing) I have arthritis in my knees.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: What the fuck is happening to us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josh waits outside an apartment door. A shirtless eight y old boy opens the door. Josh nods at him. Tim opens the door further.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Hey, man, I’m sorry about...not paying you.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I mean, I hoped the money would come in... It didn’t. I kind of fudged that.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: I just can’t work for nothing, you know? The kid shakes Josh’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: But thanks for hooking me up with Jamie, I’ve been freelancing a bit for him.  60 94.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: If you’re not too busy there, I want to hire you back for a couple of weeks. I can pay you.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Did the grant money come in?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: No, I sold all my CD’s. And some other things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tim and Josh sit in front of the screen.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Leslie suggested we cut the bit on Turkish politics, I told him it was crucial because of --

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: (immediately) I think it’s a good idea.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Yeah. We got to cut something.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (relents) Okay, let’s try it. Tim puts up an image on the SCREEN. It’s Kent.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Oh, this is Jamie’s footage. Stuff I was working on... Let me... He moves to take it down.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Wait --

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Hold on that image of Kent.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Okay.  95. Tim freezes it.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (dramatically) Blow it up.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: I can’t do that on this machine.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: No. Josh leans in. He squints. His POV: CLOSE on the home-mad ice cream container in Kent’s hand. The hipster cow.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: That’s Darby’s ice cream.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: It looks like mint of some kind.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (distracted) It’s avocado. Tim unfreezes the image. We ZOOM in on Jamie.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE, (ON SCREEN)
dialogues.text: ...my mom was really sick with ovarian cancer, I was pretty promiscuous, but I couldn’t love anyone, I had body issues --

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Darby was there before we were. Don’t you see, she brought Kent the ice cream.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: (confused) I know Jamie’s your friend, but to be honest, he’s kind of a prick. On SCREEN, Jamie’s open, earnest expression, his eyes wat and full of emotion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on Josh. His face is intense, his arms grip the whe  62 63 64 96.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (absent-mindedly singing) “You're playing Nintendo. That’s not what I’m doing, that’s not what I’m fuck-ing doing -- He bangs the wheel three times.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I’m fucking exposing your shit, mother fuck-ahhhhh --” EXT. KENT’S HOUSE, POUGHKEEPSIE. DAY 62 Josh rings the bell. The sister appears behind the glass. She wears a party hat.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Hey. Is Kent here? INT. KENT’S HOUSE/EXT. BACKYARD. DAY 63 Josh is lead by Kent’s sister through the house. We hear screaming in the backyard.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Is everything okay?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER
dialogues.text: My son turns seven today.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Oh, happy birthday. They walk through the small space, stepping over toys and discarded plates of food and reach a cramped, uncultivate backyard. Kent, in a top coat and tails is pulling an end streamer out of his mouth. The kids scream with delight. INT. BREITBART’S APARTMENT. SAME 64 CLOSE: Cornelia stares intently into her father’s eyes. They're inches apart.

dialogues.speaker: BREITBART
dialogues.text: You’re so intense.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: I'm focusing. We see now: Cornelia ties her Dad’s bow-tie. She’s very concentrated on the action.  97.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: (finishing) There.

dialogues.speaker: BREITBART
dialogues.text: Thank you. He looks at himself in the mirror and approves.

dialogues.speaker: BREITBART
dialogues.text: It’s been very strange looking back over my career. How did I accomplish all of that? If I’m honest with myself: it sometimes took being a selfish prick. Of course, you can’t say that. In my speech I attribute it to talent, work and luck. It’s something I don’t think your husband realizes. He still believes the speeches.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: When I first started dating him, he reminded me so much of you.

dialogues.speaker: BREITBART
dialogues.text: His problem is he wants what I have but he’s not merciless enough to get it.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: (simply and sadly) You know I am disappointed in Josh. On some level I feel like he failed. But I don’t know if I actually feel that because I feel that or I feel it because he does. Either way it’s a terrible thing to think about your husband.

dialogues.speaker: BREITBART
dialogues.text: You know, Josh told me... I didn’t know you miscarried.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: A few times. The magic of youth is that every decision is the right one and you don’t have to make any of them. The terror of adulthood is there are limited options and you have to pick.  65 98.

dialogues.speaker: BREITBART
dialogues.text: There’s no magic in being old. Some asshole tried to offer me a seat on the subway yesterday. She smiles. She takes her phone from her pocket and check it. No calls.

dialogues.speaker: BREITBART
dialogues.text: You young people are always checking your devices.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: (embarrassed) I’m sorry...it’s habit. EXT. KENT’S BACKYARD. DAY 65 The kids smash a pinata with a baseball bat. Josh eats birthday cake off of a Space themed plate. Kent still in his magician clothes, does tricks for kids as th come by.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: I learned magic from a dude, Elvin, over in Afghanistan. He was shredded by a land mine.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: That’s terrible.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: I’m more old fashioned in my approach. I don’t lock myself ina box or anything, it’s mostly cards and balls. I learn from YouTube videos. It keeps me from going out of my head.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Yeah...we need distractions. For me it’s the internet. I’m trying to go on less, you know. You know, it’s like how many times can I check the Huffington Post? Kent does a card trick for some kids.

dialogues.speaker: KID
dialogues.text: It’s in your other hand! Kent opens his hand, the card is gone.  99.

dialogues.speaker: KID
dialogues.text: How did you fucking do that?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER
dialogues.text: Louis!

dialogues.speaker: KID JOSH
dialogues.text: Sorry. What made you contact Jamie on Facebook? Kent looks at Josh strangely. Josh shovels a piece of cak into his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (clears his throat) What made you reach out to him?

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: I didn’t. He contacted me. Kent indicates to Josh that he has icing on his face. Jos wipes at it.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Other side. I had no idea who he was.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: He said he lived with Darby and that we'd gone to school in Santa Cruz together for a short time in the 90's. A kid hits Josh in the leg with the bat.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Ow! Fuck!

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Louis, don’t be a prick!

dialogues.speaker: KID
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: (to Josh) And you, language.  100.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Sorry. (beat) But you remembered Darby...

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Darby’s been a good friend for years. We'd Skype sometimes when I was in Kandahar. The reception was really shitty though. It would freeze up all the time.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Did she know about...that you were in the hospital? Kent hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Who are you again?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I’m Jamie’s cameraman.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: And why are you asking this stuff?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Fact checking the movie?

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Uh huh. Yeah, Darby knew. Darby was the first person I called. She came to visit a few times before you guys arrived. Some kids knock Kent’s top hat off and run with it across garden. Kent!

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Bring that back, you fuckers!

dialogues.speaker: SISTER KENT
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: What did you think when Jamie talked about Darby’s childhood as if it was his own?

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: He said he was playing a part.  66 101.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: He said that when?

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: He called me a week or so before you guys came up and filmed me. Josh reaches into his pocket and takes out a small portab video camera. He turns it on and shoots Kent.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Can you say that again? INT. BREITBART’S APARTMENT. DAY 66 Cornelia, on her phone, has stepped away from her Dad who practices his speech in the background. She gets Josh’s voice-mail.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: Josh...it’s me...again...I just...I am so sorry...I hope you come to my Dad’s thing, he’d like it and I'd like it and...I’m so sorry for all the things we said and I said and...I haven't said and...I’ve said but haven't said to you. This sounds cryptic, and maybe insane, but it’s not. I just, can you call me back? Can you come, please? (beat) Where are you, Josh? The doorbell rings. She brightens.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: Wait! Maybe this is you! She hangs up and hurries to the door.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: I got it! She opens the door: a hand extends from behind the wall, clutching a dozen roses. She is touched:

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: Josh, I... Jamie steps into the door-frame.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Jamie, actually. Don’t worry, it’s not weird. These are for your dad.  67 68 102. Cornelia’s expression drops.

dialogues.speaker: BREITBART, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: There he is!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josh leans on the buzzer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darby opens the door. A duffle bag and suitcase, computer and cat carrier with mewing cats are at her feet. Josh enters. He’s sweaty and dirty and angry and out of breath from the trip.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I’ve got to talk to Jamie!

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: He’s not here.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Are you going somewhere?

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: (embarrassed) Tampa. If I stay here any longer I‘1l girl interrupt.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I was just with Kent.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: (with real feeling) Oh...Kent...I love Kent...

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I saw your ice cream in Jamie's video. Darby nods. She smiles sadly.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: Well played, sir.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: He let me think I was the one who found out about Kent in Afghanistan. Why?

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: Jamie doesn’t want to disappoint you. None of us want to disappoint you. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: DARBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're such a purist. Jamie would never have made the movie without Afghanistan. When I told him about Kent and the massacre he thought it would make a good movie. He just had to figure out how to tell it.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: But why not tell it honestly?

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: It’s more entertaining this way. (beat) And now it has a before and after which, as you know, Americans love.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Of course he had body issues, they were yours. (off her look) I don’t mean, of course you had body issues, but... (pause) People have to know. He can’t get away with this.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: Jamie does whatever he wants.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: This goes against everything he said he admired in me. The whole principle of making a doc. Darby, you don’t understand. This is fraud. It’s a big deal. People are jailed for this kind of thing.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: I don’t like to meddle with people. If they’re going to change, they’1l change.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Where is he?

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: He’s at your father-in-law’s tribute.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (realizes) Oh, shit! That’s now! And I returned the rental car. (ve: his appearance) I’m a mess.  69 70 71 72 Blue (09/16/2013) 104.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: I can give you a jacket. And you can take Jamie’s roller blades.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: (she goes to retrieve the items ) You know, me and Jamie always wondered how are we going to get old and the answer is: just like everyone else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josh, in a thrift store jacket over a hoody, jeans and sneakers attempts to roller blade, trying to get some momentum, but he can’t really skate. A woman, 50’s, on a Bike whizzes by him. A little kid on a scooter rolls past

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Breitbart and Cornelia enter the building among suited patrons. Photographers shoot Breitbart who wears a suit w a scarf. Jamie hangs back. He’s more dapper than we’ve se him in a suit and wide colorful tie.

dialogues.speaker: PHOTOGRAPHER
dialogues.text: Can we get one with you and your daughter! Breitbart takes Cornelia’s hand. Cameras click. Then Jami steps into the shot. More cameras click. A photographer leans in to Jamie, holding a pad and pen.

dialogues.speaker: PHOTOGRAPHER
dialogues.text: What’s your name?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Me? Jamie Massey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tables are set up for a big dinner. Breitbart and Corneli take their seats. Dave leans over from an adjacent table shakes Breitbart’s hand. Jamie plops down next to Corneli  Blue (09/16/2013) 104A.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Jeez Louise. I’ve never been to a rat fuck like this. Did you see Lou Reed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Josh appear on the horizon, blading toward us. He’ getting the hang of it now. We come in CLOSE on his inten determined face. He can do this!

dialogues.speaker: D73 INT/EXT. JEFFERSON AVENUE SUBWAY STATION STEPS D73
dialogues.text: Josh, jerkily descends sideways, clutching the railing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josh rolls through, swiping as the passes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josh stands in his blades holding onto the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josh stands in his blades pushing the walk button. Cars whizz in front of him.  73 74 Blue (09/16/2013) 105.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josh blades across the plaza.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josh enters from the back, disheveled and on his blades. He rolls to a railing that looks over the reception. The lights have dimmed and on a screen: A black and white CLI from the 60’s of a little boy getting a bath. Josh scans the tables and finds Breitbart’s group. The CLIP ends to applause. Jamie leans over and says something to Cornelia. She nods. Her gaze goes in Josh’s direction. Josh rolls backward and steps behind the bar.

dialogues.speaker: OLDER PATRON
dialogues.text: Can I get a Shirley Temple? Josh nods and starts to pour her drink. The bartender sta at him.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: What are you doing, dude?  Blue (09/16/2013) 106.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Can I stand here for a second?

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: No. Josh grabs a bottle of whiskey and rolls behind a plant. removes his blades and stashes them in the planter. Jamie gets up from the table and walks toward the rest-rooms. J slugs from his whiskey bottle, and follows along the back the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wide carpeted room with high ceilings. A view of the pa Jamie looks out the window. Josh appears behind him. Jami turns around, startled.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Yoshy! (beat) You okay? Is that my jacket? Are those my blades?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) Are they? Who knows, maybe they’re Darby's. Darby's, yours, mine. Cookie O’Puss.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: (unfazed by Josh’s dig) Where have you been? Everyone's asking about you.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (slugs from the bottle) I was in Poughkeepsie.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Okay. Jamie watches Josh for a beat.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: It seems like you made a whole lot of stuff up. Applause from the other room.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: I don’t want to miss his speech

dialogues.speaker: INT. DINING HALL. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Breitbart takes the stage.

dialogues.speaker: BREITBART
dialogues.text: I’ve been thinking of tonight as my memorial for so long I had completely forgotten I had to actually be alive for it. (laughter) I was hoping I could just sleep through it...

dialogues.speaker: INT. LOBBY. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Josh and Jamie.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: You know, it’s your responsibility to be honest. People are going to believe it.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: I didn’t do anything nobody else does --

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (trying to make sense of that sentence) “I didn’t do anything nobody else...” You reveal everything and nothing. (beat, composes himself) You said you wanted to be a real documentarian.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I thought you were about process. Process and...ice cream. But you really will do anything to be successful...

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Success isn’t my thing, Josh. It’s yours. Josh is about respond, he hesitates. Nods.  108.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Yeah, you're right, it is my thing. I have a fucked up relationship with success. I want it and I don’t have it. But what you have scares the shit out of me. You’re not uncomfortable at all.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Why should I be uncomfortable?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: See, that I just find weird.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: You're the only person who is weird about this. I asked you to co-direct --

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Yeah, because you knew I'd say, No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Breitbart’s speech.

dialogues.speaker: BREITBART
dialogues.text: Now people have criticized me and some of my colleagues saying that we were pretending to be objective when there is no objectivity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josh and Jamie.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Jeez, Joshy. Everyone does this kind of thing.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I don’t. I don’t do something like this. I’m trying to make movies to figure out the truth.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: (incredulous ) Really?  80 81 82 109.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Yes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Breitbart.

dialogues.speaker: BREITBART
dialogues.text: Okay, we were trying to capture truth, but the truth of experience, of being in the moment, of seeing something as it happens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josh and Jamie.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (sadly) I do know that documentaries are over.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Are you kidding? It’s what everyone is doing.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (indicating Breitbart) His documentaries are over. What you're doing is something else. If everyone is filming everything, what’s a documentary anymore? It has no meaning, it’s just shit you recorded! Is that old man talk? Maybe it is. You kids have been told you can do anything. You can’t. (beat) Well, you, Jamie, can, but most people can’t. Jamie shrugs. Josh, annoyed, imitates him by shrugging ba

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Breitbart.  110.

dialogues.speaker: BREITBART
dialogues.text: What we were trying to say as filmmakers is that what we were filming was more interesting than we were...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josh and Jamie.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: You think everything is out there for you to have. It’s not.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Nobody owns anything. If I hear a song I like, or a story, it’s mine. It’s mine to use. It’s everybody's.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: No it isn’t! That’s not sharing Jamie, that’s...stealing.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: That’s old man talk.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I am an old man! Applause as Breitbart finishes his speech. Josh, embolden turns to Jamie.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I can’t let Cornelia and Leslie walk down this road with you. I want you to go in there and tell them what you’ve done. If you won’t, I’1l do it for you. For a brief moment, Jamie’s face elicits what looks like fear. It passes.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, kid. But there are standards, there are...standards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josh walks with purpose toward the table. Jamie trails behind him.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: Josh!

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Sorry I’m late. (to Breitbart) Leslie, I caught your speech from the lobby, though and it was really inspiring, spot on...

dialogues.speaker: BREITBART
dialogues.text: Are you okay, son? Do you want to sit down?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Jamie has something he wants to tell all of you. Josh takes a seat and crosses his legs comfortably.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Go ahead. They all look at him and then Jamie blankly.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Not all of the stuff in my movie happened exactly as I said it did. (sighs) I played around with some of the time- line.

dialogues.speaker: BREITBART
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: (humbly) Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: “Yeah?” And...

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: And what?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: You did a lot more than that, come on. Josh stands back up. He says to the table:  112.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: He didn’t even know Kent. Darby did. And Darby’s mother died of ovarian cancer. Jamie’s mom is probably alive and kicking in Idaho. He sits back down.

dialogues.speaker: BREITBART
dialogues.text: (trying to put an end to it) Josh, this is kind of my night --

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: You just need to hear this.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: That's basically it. Josh leaps back up.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: No, that’s not basically it! You knew that Kent had tried to kill himself...

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Say it!

dialogues.speaker: BREITBART
dialogues.text: Josh, come on, let him speak.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: The gist is the same. I authored a bit of how we came to it. I mean, I’m not that good a writer. If I made it all up, I'd be the best writer in Hollywood and...and Kent would be Marlon Brando. Breitbart laughs. Hedge Fund Dave laughs harder.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I never said it was amazing. I just said it was faked.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: And some of the time-line was adjusted --  113.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Stop with the time-line crap! Josh pulls out his video camera and gestures with it.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Jamie knew that Kent tried to kill himself. That he’d been in Afghanistan. We didn’t just stumble upon it. It was rigged. Jamie invented the whole Facebook thing because he knew it would play better.

dialogues.speaker: HEDGE FUND DAVE
dialogues.text: Kent wasn’t in Afghanistan?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: No, Kent was in Afghanistan.

dialogues.speaker: HEDGE FUND DAVE
dialogues.text: So, what’s the problem?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: It’s...it’s...the way, the way he said that he found him is not true.

dialogues.speaker: HEDGE FUND DAVE
dialogues.text: Kent served our country, you’re being offensive. Breitbart looks at Jamie.

dialogues.speaker: BREITBART
dialogues.text: Is what Josh is saying true?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Well...I did know, but I don’t think it really matters though, the movie’s not about that.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Of course it matters. Leslie, explain...

dialogues.speaker: BREITBART
dialogues.text: I don’t know that it matters totally in this case.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (shocked) What? Dave leans in from the next table.  114.

dialogues.speaker: HEDGE FUND DAVE
dialogues.text: I don’t care.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (dismissive) I didn’t expect you to care. (quickly back to Leslie) Leslie, are you kidding me? You don’t care? You just gave a speech about authenticity!

dialogues.speaker: HEDGE FUND DAVE
dialogues.text: (thinks about it again) Yeah, I don’t care.

dialogues.speaker: BREITBART
dialogues.text: I just think the movie works on many levels, the happenstance of it, to be honest, I find the least interesting part. Josh sputters, practically stomps his foot.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I can’t believe it! This movie isn’t worth the...RAM...it’s...stored on. (pointing at Jamie) He’s acon artist. Leslie, your generation of sit-ins and protesters and...pack rats would be horrified by this...demon!

dialogues.speaker: BREITBART
dialogues.text: You're hysterical, Josh.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (hysterically) I’m not hysterical! He swings his arm, gesturing, knocking a tray full of foo and glasses out of a waiter’s arms. It goes crashing to t ground.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Shit, I’m sorry, I’m sorry. He helps the waiter pick up the plates. Everyone at the table waits. Josh finally gets back up.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Cornelia...  115.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I think he’s an asshole, but the movie’s pretty good. And I'm sorry I think that. Jamie takes a seat and starts eating the dessert that was placed in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: This is so frustrating! I’m going to get no satisfaction here, am I? This guy’s just going to win no matter what. Everyone at the table stares at Josh. His says with certainty:

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: This is not how the world works. We MOVE in on Josh. His face fills with emotion.

dialogues.speaker: BREITBART
dialogues.text: Why does it have to be one thing or another? Things change. Different things matter now.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Forget ethics then. What about me?! You played me. I was played.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: (under his breath) But you acted in it.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Only because I thought it was real! (pause, with genuine feeling) I loved you.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: I like you too! We’re friends.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (sadly) I really believed it. (his throat full of sadness) I was a bet!

dialogues.speaker: BREITBART
dialogues.text: Are you okay, son?  85 Blue (09/16/2013) 116. Josh wipes his face.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I’m not crying. I’m not. Josh's attention goes to a tiny camera in Jamie’s lap aim right at him.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Are you filming this?!

dialogues.speaker: BREITBART
dialogues.text: Josh, your sleeve is on fire. Josh's sweatshirt has dipped into the flame of a candle o the table and is indeed on fire. Jamie stands, grabs a pitcher of water and douses Josh. Josh drips, soaked. He shakes his head like a wet dog and dejected, moves to leave. He hesitates and turns to Breit

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I took your note by the way. I cut the stuff on Turkish politics out of my film. You were right, I don’t need it.

dialogues.speaker: BREITBART
dialogues.text: I’m glad to hear that, son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE: Kent, in his magician outfit, speaks to the camera DELETE? comes up on the SCREEN. YES is selected. The file is deleted. Josh puts the video camera back in his tote. He sits on t steps with his roller blades and whiskey bottle. Cornelia arrives. She holds a plate with a napkin covering it. She hands it to Josh.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: It doesn’t matter that it’s faked. (Josh nods) It doesn’t matter because it’s not about Afghanistan and it’s not about Kent it’s about Jamie.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (sighs) In my head, when I was blading over, I swept in here and exposed everything. I was such a hero.  117. He lifts the napkin on the plate to see a piece of chocol cake drizzled with chocolate sauce and a fork.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Thanks. Cornelia takes a swig from the bottle.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: When we first started seeing each other I was so jealous. I would get so upset when you’d talk to another girl at a party.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I know! I liked that...

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: I was so sure you’d fall in love with someone else and leave me.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Did you want me to?

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: I think I wanted to know that I wasn’t your only option. But you didn’t fall in love with someone else. Until you did. And then it was two people. (beat) I’m so sorry I kissed him. I really did think it was you at first...then I kind of kissed him again. I don’t know why I did it. I wanted to like him as much as you did. Josh starts to eat the cake.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (mouth full) I wanted so badly...I wanted to be admired. I wanted a protege.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: He looked at me like I was a real grown-up person. Someone who has done things. For the first time in my life I stopped thinking of myself as a child imitating an adult.  Blue (09/16/2013) 118.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: You feel that way too?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (nods ) I’m forty-four and there are things I will never do. Things I won’t have. (pause) What’s the opposite of “the world’s your oyster?” Cornelia’s eyes water. She nods.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: I think I stopped taking you in.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Am I a failure?

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: You’ve never failed me.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: But am I a failure?

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: I feel like I failed you. I wish we could go back and meet each other all over again.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I'd present myself differently. So I didn’t get your hopes up. Maybe not use the expression “conquer the world” so often.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: You said that a lot.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I think it’s hard for me to have something be great every day and to acknowledge it. (smiles at her) I have something great every day. If we were different people, I’d ask you to renew our vows.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: I think it’s nice to renew vows.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Maybe we are different people.  86 Blue (09/16/2013) 118A. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: What are you thinking about?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Twenty years ago I was twenty-four. In twenty years I'll be sixty-four.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on Willow, a year older, in a car seat.

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: Pink (09/30/2013) 119. Fletcher drives, Marina in the passenger seat. Josh and Cornelia in the back with Willow. Fletcher pulls up to th terminal.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: Call when you get there!

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: We will, Fox. Josh and Cornelia get out of the car and grab the bags fr the trunk. Marina joins them. Fletcher steps out of the car, but hangs by the door.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: You're going to be such great parents.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: The guy is waving at me, we have to move, Marina! They changed the rules. (to Josh and Cornelia) See you when you get back. Marina hugs both of them.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: Oh, Fox, I’m going to cry.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER JOSH
dialogues.text: The cop is coming, Marina! We'll be back in a week.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: Send pictures of the little man! We love you guys.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: We love you too!

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I love you, Fletcher.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: I love you too but I’m not getting arrested for you. Marina!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE: An airplane departure screen. JFK to Port-au-Princ Haiti.  88 Josh sits outside the gate, bags at his feet. He plays game on his phone. Cornelia sits down next to him with stack of magazines. She hands Josh a yogurt.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Thanks. (re: her stack of magazines) You really need ten?

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: It’s three and half hours to Port-au- Prince. 120. a a Cornelia slides a photo of a Haitian baby out from betwee the pages of a hard cover book. She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: I can’t believe it.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Me neither. He takes the photo from her. He gazes happily at it. opens a magazine.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: Oh...look who it is. She She presents the magazine for Josh to see: CLOSE on a PHO of Jamie at Sundance. CLOSE on the PULL QUOTE: “Are you a hipster?” “Well, I’m of a certain age and I wear tight jeans.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamie, in a black trenchcoat and a knit cap, is being interviewed by a cute interviewer in a parka.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: But I’m just about out of the cool- age demographic.

dialogues.speaker: INTERVIEWER
dialogues.text: What happens when you exit the cool- age demographic? Jamie thinks about this. 88  89 90 91 121.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: I enter the power-age demographic. We MOVE down to Jamie’s lap. He holds a small video camer trained on the interviewer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josh hands the magazine back to Cornelia.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: It’s out there. The evil is unleashed.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: No, you were right, he’s not evil. He’s just young.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: I heard from Darby, she Facebooked me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darby, her hair in a braid, a name-tag on her shirt which a parrot on it, runs a net through mud. A motorboat behin her.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: She's an eco-tourguide at a wildlife refuge.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: This mud is filled with organisms. She sticks her hand in the mud and pulls out a worm-like thing.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: This is a nudibranch. And if you keep your eyes peeled you might spot a gopher tortoise or a woodstork.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josh opens his yogurt. He pauses for a moment, looking at the container.  92 122.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: (frowns ) What’s wrong?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: No. Nothing. We’ll have a baby before this yogurt expires. Cornelia suddenly leans in hard, her face colliding with Josh’s.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (laughs) Oww, your teeth. They kiss long, intimately. Finally, they release. Both a grinning. In the row of seats across from them: A mom is going thro her tickets and itinerary. Her toe-headed one year old so is on his iPhone. Josh and Cornelia watch the little boy -- his fingers mov quickly, gracefully on the keys. He’s totally immersed in what he’s doing. Nothing else exists. Then he puts it to his ear. We CUT TO: BLACK. As the CREDITS ROLL we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A VIDEO IMAGE of Josh. He sits in an armchair looking at camera. He consults a piece of loose-leaf paper, and with Cornelia’s help from behind the camera, re-asks his ten y  123. worth of questions for his documentary.
